column1:
It’s true. You talk too much. How to be a better listener: http://on.wsj.com/1b3VqFg

In an optimal conversation, each person talks about 50% of the time. What are your tips for having better conversations?

Photo illustration by Serge Bloch; Getty Images (teeth)

A monster truck rally accident left 8 dead and 79 injured Saturday, when a truck went out of control and plunged into a crowd of spectators in Chihuahua, Mexico. http://on.wsj.com/19vw53L

Photo: El Diario de Chihuahua

There's little correlation between the most-watched shows on TV and the ones that are tweeted about the most, new Nielsen data show. http://on.wsj.com/199pyQ9

CBS had 5 of the top 10 shows on TV during the week of Sept. 23, including "The Big Bang Theory." None of those was in the top 10 of the Twitter TV ratings.

Here's a 6-step plan to address your 401(k) if you're within, say, 10 years of retirement: http://on.wsj.com/1fcJu8Z

Step 1: If you haven't done it lately, review your 401(k) investment mix.

What are you doing to prepare for retirement?

The human supermarket checker is superior to the self-checkout machine in almost every way, one analyst says. http://bit.ly/1a53UJQ

Checking out groceries requires just enough mental-processing skills to be a challenge for computers.

What's your experience with humans v. machines at the grocery store?

Credit: Bloomberg News

South Korea has the highest suicide rate in the developed world. Though still high, the rate has fallen for the first time in 6 years. http://on.wsj.com/1b28hrB 

The national rate was 28.1 per 100,000 in 2012, down from 31.7 a year earlier. That’s still more than double the average of 12.5 for members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Credit: Reuters

In parts of India, old wives’ tales about women’s impurity during menstruation persist. http://on.wsj.com/19t3p18
 
Some of the strictures still in place for women during their monthly period include: 

Don’t enter the kitchen.
Don’t touch the pickles. 
Don’t go into the wine cellar. 
Don't swim.

This painting by Zeng Fanzhi sold for $23.3 million at a Sotheby’s auction in Hong Kong, setting a new record price for a work by an Asian contemporary artist. http://on.wsj.com/18IKeh3

What do you think about the work?

Credit: European Pressphoto Agency

Retail rents in the world's most expensive market are finally cooling following a slowdown in growth in luxury spending. http://on.wsj.com/1fbtRyv

Explore this interactive map of rising rents in key street-level shopping districts in Hong Kong: http://on.wsj.com/1clqjZu

The tourism industry of a small village in Northern Scotland is being torn apart by a monstrous fight. A recently faked picture of the Loch Ness Monster has exposed a bitter truth: some key players in the Nessie industry don't believe the monster exists. http://on.wsj.com/1geITT5

The nonprofit Center for Pet Safety in Reston, Va., has teamed up with auto maker Subaru to run tests on 11 pet safety belts. http://on.wsj.com/1a7D3hB

For the tests, the center designed some of the world's first crash-test "dummy" dogs.

Photo: Center for Pet Safety
Where are the most expensive places in the U.S. to remodel a home? The Northeast tops a new survey: http://on.wsj.com/1bx6SNW

One man is on a mission to collect and photograph all the Apple products ever made: http://on.wsj.com/1gbbZTp

What is your favorite Apple product?

Pictured, the Lisa Mouse from 1983. (Credit: Jonathan Zufi)
Women with a university degree are almost twice as likely to drink alcohol on a daily basis as those without. The new face of risky drinking is female: http://on.wsj.com/18Z3q91
Detroit Tigers' third baseman, Miguel Cabrera, has numbers that stun the baseball world, even though his style defies years of baseball wisdom. How he does it: http://on.wsj.com/1f5yOc4
Make way for Thanksgivukkah. This year, Thanksgiving and the first day of Hanukkah fall on the same date: Nov. 28. This may not happen again for another 70,000+ years.

How Twitter stacks up against Facebook, Google, LinkedIn and other tech companies when they filed for an IPO: http://on.wsj.com/GCxVK9

Do you think Twitter will be a good investment?

China has issued new guidelines for Chinese tourists abroad to try to improve their notoriously bad reputation. http://on.wsj.com/GCl6iN

The 64-page animated handbook includes rules such as:

Don’t pick your nose in public.
Don’t sneeze in front of others.
Don’t leave footprints on the toilet.

What etiquette rules do you follow when traveling?

Twitter has officially filed paperwork for an IPO. The filing says Twitter will seek to raise up to $1 billion. Its ticker symbol will be TWTR. Follow our live updates and analysis: http://on.wsj.com/18BuI6C

Would you invest in Twitter?

Photo: AFP/Getty Images

A genomics company in California has been awarded a broad U.S. patent for a technique that could create "designer babies." http://on.wsj.com/16IX15I

That means parents could select genes to boost the chances of a child having certain physical traits like a particular eye or hair color.

Would you use this technique?

Update: Police ended the lockdown on the U.S. Capitol after reports of gunshots being fired outside the building. An official said the incident involved a car chase. http://on.wsj.com/1g7V307

Photo: People run for cover as police converge on Capitol Hill. (Credit: AFP/Getty)

Most airlines say they never use 13 and 911 for flight numbers. And tradition holds that the flight numbers of crashed planes are never used again. Meanwhile, flights to Las Vegas are more likely to include the number "7."

What do you think of superstitions based on numbers?
The U.S. is on pace to overtake Russia as the world's largest producer of oil and natural gas. How countries compare: http://on.wsj.com/1btEYm1

Facebook is planning to build a 394-unit housing community near its corporate campus: http://on.wsj.com/1fLq4cz

Amenities for residents will include a cafe, a convenience store, a sports pub, a pet spa with doggy day care, and a resort-inspired pool, spa and cabana area, among other things.

Would you choose to live in corporate housing?

Credit: Renderings of Facebook's planned Anton Menlo Community housing.
Obama and congressional leaders emerged from a meeting with no evidence of progress toward resolving their impasse over health care and government spending. http://on.wsj.com/1f2cAYE

In an age of "binge-viewing," TV theme songs are becoming more important for the success of a show. http://on.wsj.com/16ikcBy

A familiar song can provide an anchor for a series and preserve the sense of ritual attached to following it.

What's your favorite TV theme song? 

Photo: 20th Century Fox/Everett Collection

Giant explosive volcanoes blasted primordial Mars, spewing ash across half the planet and possibly changing its climate, researchers said. http://on.wsj.com/19ZzbPv

Photo: This composite satellite image shows a 3-D view of Eden Patera, an ancient supervolcano on Mars. (ESA/Mars Express/Freie Universitat Berlin)

Many companies make the mistake of listing too many requirements in their job ads, deterring qualified candidates from applying.

Would you apply for a job if you didn't meet every single requirement?

"It's kind of a Xanax in a can." Skip the Red Bull. People are turning to relaxation drinks to unwind: http://on.wsj.com/1g3OITk

Would you try one of these beverages to relax?

Illustration: Serge Bloch

Two hundred patients, including 30 children, are going to be turned away from the NIH's Clinical Center due to the government shutdown: http://on.wsj.com/1bvdzwl

Are you affected by the shutdown? Share your stories. We’ll use some of your replies in our ongoing coverage of the budget battle. http://on.wsj.com/19SYykV

5 things Millennials should discuss before they get married: http://on.wsj.com/GzIEVu

1. Student loans
2. Making a budget
3. Planning for children
4. Combining finances
5. Retirement

What other issues are important to discuss before getting married?

KFC spent two years developing the KFC Go Cup, a plastic container that holds bite-size chicken and potato wedges.  http://on.wsj.com/1dW1G3z

KFC believes the cup fits 83% of U.S. cars' cup holders.

What foods are you most likely to eat on the go?

The government shutdown doesn't show signs of ending quickly, as House Republicans today came up with a plan to fund the government piece by piece. http://on.wsj.com/16VSvu3

House Republicans are expected to bring up three bills later Tuesday to restore funding for veterans' services, national parks and D.C. Schools through Dec. 15.

What do you think of the plan?

The new online insurance marketplaces opened today. However, technical glitches have prevented many from enrolling. http://on.wsj.com/1hiXqek

One reason for the delays and technical problems was a flood of interest, officials said.

Countries that treat workers the best, according to the World Economic Forum: http://on.wsj.com/18pOd1T

1. Switzerland
2. Finland
3. Singapore
4. Netherlands
5. Sweden
6. Germany
7. Norway
8. United Kingdom
9. Denmark
10. Canada

People struggling to pay student loans who file for bankruptcy often end up owing even more at the end of the process. http://on.wsj.com/15J1kbj

Under the bankruptcy code, consumers can almost never get rid of student loans—unlike credit-card, medical and many other types of debt. What do you think of this rule?

Studies show hospital staff, on average, comply with hand-washing protocols only about 50% of the time. http://on.wsj.com/1aIfi0i

Hospitals are encouraging patients to ask their doctor or nurse to wash their hands. 

Credit: CDC

Entering into intimate relationships too early can leave teens ill-prepared to handle typical problems couples face and without the support of peers at the same stage of romantic development, researchers said.

The U.S. government's shutdown will send more than 800,000 federal workers home without pay and close national parks. Get the latest news and updates here: 
http://on.wsj.com/YPPFX0

Are you affected by the shutdown? We’ll use some of your replies in our ongoing coverage of the budget battle. http://on.wsj.com/19SYykV

What would you like to see Congress do to resolve this budget battle?

Credit: Jason Reed/Reuters
In a surprise discovery, doctors have found that a heart pump that is used to help keep patients alive until a transplant can happen may actually help the heart heal itself: http://on.wsj.com/1fFtugO

Ever wondered what it cost to make an iPhone? Here's a breakdown: http://on.wsj.com/GzvUxO

Is it more/less than what you thought?

The White House has directed federal agencies to implement shutdown plans as Congress failed to resolve a standoff over spending and the health-care law. http://on.wsj.com/GzvuYn

Here’s what to expect: http://on.wsj.com/1aGtk2B

What do you think about the shut down? Follow coverage here: http://on.wsj.com/1bYX3Yv

E. coli can (A) make you very sick, or (B) provide gasoline for your car. 

Korean scientists say B. Here’s how it works: http://on.wsj.com/18HLKAE

Though bacteria-powered cars are still far off, what do you think about the findings?

Credit: Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology

New research shows that New York City cockroaches tend to stay in the neighborhoods they grew up in and segregate themselves. http://on.wsj.com/15ENCeP

The cockroaches' ancestors likely came to America as stowaways, the study finds.

The looming government shutdown would prompt federal agencies to suspend many activities and furlough at least 825,000 of the U.S. government's workers.

Do you think a government shutdown can be averted? Who is to blame?

Most valuable brands, according to an annual ranking by Interbrand: http://on.wsj.com/19QTkpE

1. Apple
2. Google
3. Coca-Cola
4. IBM
5. Microsoft
6. GE
7. McDonald's
8. Samsung
9. Intel
10. Toyota

On average, young Americans are now 30 years old when they first earn $42,000 -- a marker of financial independence -- up from 26 years old in 1980. http://on.wsj.com/18l0moI

Pictured: James Roy, 26, is now working at a coffee shop to pay off $14,000 in student loans for two years of college. (Credit: Caroline Porter/The Wall Street Journal)

What tips do you have on how millennials can succeed?
Before deciding to fund a startup, more investors are taking social media into consideration: http://on.wsj.com/19c9rDe

In a bid to compete with Twitter TV ratings, Facebook will start sending weekly data reports to ABC, NBC, Fox and CBS: http://on.wsj.com/18FYequ

The reports will show how many Facebook likes, comments, or shares a TV episode has gotten and how many members participated in the action.

What social network do you use to chat about your favorite TV show? Why?

What's next for stocks? Find out in a live video chat with WSJ reporters and analysts at 12 p.m. ET: http://bit.ly/1fCTSIg

Make your own predictions about the S&P 500 with the WSJ stocks game: http://on.wsj.com/19iWd1v
You don't have to be an entrepreneur to have a great idea for a business. And you don't need to start a business to profit from a great idea. Some tips for both: http://on.wsj.com/1eU4P71

Internet spying by the NSA has led some countries, including Germany, to see a business opportunity - keeping data safe from prying eyes: http://on.wsj.com/1dRPeSh

"Countries are competing to be the Cayman Islands of data privacy," says one senior analyst.

Would you store your data in an off-shore account?

China is having a tough time producing world-class innovations. http://on.wsj.com/1fVsToU

Heavy spending on research and development has tried to boost new ideas, but will it work?

A five-story building in Mumbai collapsed Friday killing 61 people. A shop owner remains in custody. http://on.wsj.com/16CM99u
 
This is the latest in a series of deadly building collapses in India, which are often blamed on builders using poor-quality materials or failing to get the necessary licenses.

Photo: A survivor rescued from the building. (European Pressphoto Agency)

China will test a looser grip on its economy with the opening of a free-trade zone, which will allow wholly foreign-owned banks to open there for the first time. http://on.wsj.com/1bl8gTz

Do you think the zone—a laboratory for remaking the country's financial sector—will be a game changer or a disappointment? http://on.wsj.com/1aDnvCW

Credit: Reuters

High-design hotels combine stunning architecture with beautiful natural surroundings: http://on.wsj.com/16V5ugq

On shores of Lake Taihu in eastern China, two 27-story towers form the Sheraton Huzhou Hot Spring Resort. It has 321 rooms, an indoor pool, and a lobby lounge where Swarovski crystal garlands are suspended above a 28-ton hunk of jade. 

What's your ideal design for a luxury hotel?

Credit: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide, Inc.

Colorado State University is raising money to build a $246 million, 40,000-seat football stadium, in hopes that a winning football team will attract higher-paying, out-of-state students. Critics think the project is a boondoggle. http://on.wsj.com/163jkR4

How should colleges improve their stadiums?

A recent U.N. report on global warming predicts a worst case scenario of a 4.8 degrees Celsius, or 8.6 degrees Fahrenheit increase in temperature toward the end of the century. http://on.wsj.com/179kHgY

It also suggests that the current carbon-dioxide concentration in the earth's atmosphere is 40% above preindustrial levels.

A New Jersey judge has ruled that the state must allow same-sex couples to marry. http://on.wsj.com/1aw7gHT

The judge said that now the federal government recognizes gay marriages, not doing so in New Jersey would violate the state constitution.

AMC's "Breaking Bad" airs its finale on Sunday. Will it meet audience expectations? http://on.wsj.com/1h9bWoU

WSJ readers weigh in on how they think the show will end: http://on.wsj.com/19MjFFp

How should “Breaking Bad” end?

Credit: AMC
online.wsj.com

Relief for the chronic misspellers: Facebook now allows users to edit published posts. http://on.wsj.com/1avNXyk

To edit a post, a user just needs to tap on the down arrow on the upper-right hand corner of a post, select “Edit Post” and revise their text. 

What other changes or modifications would you like to see Facebook implement?

In 1987, about 40% of Major League Baseball players had mustaches. It's only 0.4% today. http://on.wsj.com/15ZDxY8

What's your preferred type of facial hair?

Applications to Wharton's M.B.A. program have declined 12% in the past four years. It now gets fewer applicants than Stanford's business school, which has a class half the size. http://on.wsj.com/1eMCMXd

Which business school do you think is No. 1? Why?

Computer-controlled cars are coming closer to being a reality: http://on.wsj.com/188K9CZ

The question isn't "if" but "how" technology will allow humans to take a back seat to the computer, says WSJ's Dan Neil.

Would you drive a "driverless" car?

Credit: Illustration by Matt Dartford for The Wall Street Journal

Congress's is on a rocky path to a government shutdown: http://on.wsj.com/188tRdt

Speaker John Boehner said the House wouldn't accept the spending plan likely to emerge from the Senate.

What do you think Congress should do to avoid a shutdown?

Credit: Reuters

Firms including Samsung and Intel are flocking to Vietnam as shipments there of smartphones and computer parts begin to overtake exports of coffee, garments and shrimp. http://on.wsj.com/176yqoZ

Could Vietnam be Asia’s next tech hub?

Surgeons in China’s Fujian province will replace this man’s original nose that was infected after an accident, with the one being grown on his forehead. http://bit.ly/1bbBQrh

Credit: Reuters

The battle to be president of the Delhi Gymkhana Club, whose members include India’s upper crust, is raising a hullabaloo. http://on.wsj.com/19L6YdO

There are claims of “defamatory” statements, “dirty tricks” and courting votes with cocktails. What do you think about the tactics being used to win? 

Credit: Junho Kim

Children as young as 4 years old are learning to become gourmet chefs and prepare dishes like garlic aioli and yellow squash soufflé. http://on.wsj.com/16MA1Nn

This includes Sarah Lane, 9, who will debut on Fox's "MasterChef Junior," alongside Chef Gordon Ramsay. 

Credit: Sam Comen for The WSJ

Students are no longer showing up for college football games: http://on.wsj.com/1frPxrf

At the University of Georgia, for example, students left empty 39% of their designated sections over the last 4 seasons.

How would you get students back to the games?

Credit: David Walter Banks for The Wall Street Journal

A new California law gives minors more power to remove personal data they have shared online. http://on.wsj.com/1eJUJFG
 
The so-called “online eraser” bill gives teens either the right to take down videos, pictures, recordings and comments they posted online themselves or web sites must set up a way for them to request it be removed.

Should this kind of law exist in more states?

The top 10 most innovative companies to work for, according to a Boston Consulting Group survey: http://on.wsj.com/1beRVje

1. Apple
2. Samsung
3. Google
4. Microsoft
5. Toyota
6. IBM
7. Amazon
8. Ford
9. BMW
10. General Electric

Would you like to see your company place more or less emphasis on innovation? Why?

Researchers unveiled the first working computer built entirely from carbon nanotube transistors: http://on.wsj.com/1eJKzoz

If perfected, the device would allow a computer to work faster and with about one-tenth the energy, scientists say.

U.S. jails have become the largest mental-health treatment facilities in the country:  http://on.wsj.com/1fqpcK5

The country's three biggest jail systems have 11,000 prisoners under treatment on any given day. The 3 largest state-run mental hospitals have 4,000.

Several Chinese moguls have vanished amid a corruption probe, signaling a new round of political infighting. http://on.wsj.com/18rbiA3

Employees and associates of the missing business executives believe Chinese legal authorities and Communist Party investigators are holding them.

First class on Singapore Airlines has gotten even more comfortable. There are 24-inch TVs, dividers for privacy and padded headboards. http://on.wsj.com/1aqANTe

The $150 million makeover also included redesigns for the carrier’s business and economy classes. What’s your favorite airline and why? 

Credit: Michael O'Leary for The Wall Street Journal

Do you follow yacht racing? This latest race was one of the most astonishing comebacks in sporting history. Oracle Team USA returned from the edge of defeat to win 8 races against New Zealand and retain yachting's greatest trophy. http://on.wsj.com/18XYGo6

Credit: European Photopress Agency

A 32-year-old man successfully controlled movements of a bionic leg using only his own thoughts. http://on.wsj.com/1dK7woF

Photo: Andrew A. Nelles for The WSJ

Growth in the share of women entering science, technology, engineering and math fields has slowed down due to declining interest from women in computer science. http://on.wsj.com/171uaXL

In 2011, women made up 27% of computer occupations, but the number has dropped since 1990 when it was 34%.

How do you think we should bridge the gender gap?

J.P. Morgan Chase is discussing an $11 billion settlement for probes related to mortgage-backed securities: http://on.wsj.com/1fnyW7Y

The amount would include $7 billion cash and $4 billion in relief that J.P. Morgan would provide to consumers.

A very unexpected outcome from a major earthquake in Pakistan that killed more than 300 people: The sudden appearance of a small new island off the country's coast. http://on.wsj.com/19FwMYM

Credit: Reuters

After decades of going down the drain, American toilet manufacturing is making a comeback. http://on.wsj.com/170JEeE

The toilet turnaround is a microcosm of U.S. manufacturing trends. "The days of chasing cheap labor around the world are coming to an end." 

Credit: David Walter Banks for The Wall Street Journal

Those seaweed chips and brown rice crackers aren't that good for you. The rise of "healthy" snacks: http://on.wsj.com/16zqng2

These snacks' calorie, fat or sodium profiles can rival or exceed those of pretzels and potato chips. What's your preferred snack?

Credit: F. Martin Ramin/WSJ

Nearly half of eighth-graders aren't able to put three fractions in order by size: http://on.wsj.com/18pqn56

New methods for teaching fractions will rely on number lines, paper models and games that help put fractions in context.

How would you teach kids to understand fractions?

U.S. officials revealed insurance prices that will be offered through health-care exchanges starting Oct. 1: http://on.wsj.com/15TAqkt

Young buyers likely will pay more than they do currently while older consumers should get a break.

As the U.S. property market rebounds, Chinese property investors are looking beyond New York, L.A. and San Francisco to cities like Seattle, Houston and Boston. http://on.wsj.com/1gYu7O4

What about these cities are drawing investors from China?

Credit: Grand China Fund

Love can be complicated. Ever wanted to study it? One of India’s most prestigious universities is making love part of its curriculum. http://on.wsj.com/16YKskd

The class will teach different forms of love and its interplay with society and culture. Would you sign up?

Apple's smartphone market share in China is expected to double from this year to next year.  http://on.wsj.com/1fjAnnO

The rapid growth will be due mainly to Apple’s expected deal with China Mobile, which has 700 million subscribers.

Do you think Apple could eventually overtake the market share of leaders Samsung and Lenovo in China?

Credit: Bloomberg

The ratio of pay for a former J.C. Penney CEO to a former cashier at the store was 1,795 to 1. http://on.wsj.com/1eEUyvb

What do you think is a fair CEO to employee pay ratio?
Burger King is rolling out lower-fat, lower-calorie fries called "Satisfries":  http://on.wsj.com/19x3HA9

A lack of competitiveness among younger runners is turning some races into parades: http://on.wsj.com/18nJOez

"There's not as many super-competitive athletes today as when the baby boomers were in their 20s and 30s," says a spokesman for Running USA.

Do you think there's a generational difference between marathon runners?

Credit: European Pressphoto Agency

The median number of applications for full-time M.B.A. programs rose by nearly 12% for this year. http://on.wsj.com/19wMGWG

Is going to business school a good investment?
After a fall, people often say they tripped or slipped. But tripping causes just 1 out of 5 falls. The science of maintaining balance: http://on.wsj.com/19AP39D

People who help friends while expecting nothing in return are happier, new research shows. But tension can arise when one friend keeps giving and the other rarely returns the favor.

What's your philosophy about helping others?

Plenty has changed since the days of "Not in front of the children." Arguing in the open can actually be healthy for parents and kids: http://on.wsj.com/1fxRBeP

Should parents fight in front of their children or should it always be in private?

The number of people caught illegally entering the U.S. is up for a second straight year, according to federal data. http://on.wsj.com/1b90Xyk

The numbers are still far below the peak, from 1980 to 2005, when the Border Patrol averaged more than one million apprehensions a year.

Apple sold 9 million iPhones over its debut weekend, beating analysts’ expectations. http://on.wsj.com/15og0l7

However, assessing demand for the phones is difficult because more countries are involved this year, including China, which is a huge smartphone market. 

Credit: Bloomberg

Robots could supplant workers in China as pay soars and people age. http://on.wsj.com/1fwBUEN

Machines in the pipeline include high-end humanoid robots with vision, touch and even learning capabilities.

What do you think about China’s automation shift? 

Credit: Neil Wade for The Wall Street Journal

The wife, center, of one of the men sentenced to death in India’s gang-rape case expects to be cast out by her in-laws and face destitution—not because she is married to a convicted murderer, but because she is a woman without a husband. Her story: http://on.wsj.com/17YsrlB

Credit: Junho Kim/The Wall Street Journal

Fourteen states and Washington D.C. are running their own health insurance exchanges, while the other 36 are entrusting exchanges to the federal government. http://on.wsj.com/19uxw4m

What do you think of the state-by-state differences?

Who drives electric cars? A close-up look at a small but fast-growing group of Americans: http://on.wsj.com/1aiLN5e

Are electric cars the future of the automotive industry? Would you buy one?

BlackBerry has agreed to be acquired by a group led by Fairfax Financial Holdings for about $4.7 billion. http://on.wsj.com/15mu4Gx

Fairfax is one of BlackBerry's most prominent investors, owning 10% of BlackBerry's shares. The deal calls for BlackBerry shareholders to receive $9 a share.

What are your predictions for what's next for BlackBerry?

Is a smartphone a dumb idea for kids? Some guidelines for when - and if - you decide to get a phone for your children: http://on.wsj.com/15Pky2i

At what age do you think it's appropriate to have a cell phone?

Hedge funds and other investors are using Freedom of Information Act requests to obtain nonpublic information from the FDA and other agencies. http://on.wsj.com/1aihyeB

Investors say they rarely make trades solely based on information obtained through the open-records law, but that such material helps them to piece together investment strategies. 

What do you think of this tactic? Does it create an unfair advantage?
blogs.wsj.com

How do you predict Breaking Bad will end? And if you were in control of the show, how would you choose to wrap things up? http://on.wsj.com/19to8xW

Share your theories. We'll feature the best ones online and in the print Wall Street Journal.

Credit: Ursula Coyote/AMC

Chocolate prices are on the rise. One kilogram of chocolate will cost a record $12.25 this year: http://on.wsj.com/1faX8uc

Americans and Europeans are buying more dark chocolate for health and economic reasons. "People are going back to an impulse buy," said one chocolate producer.

Will you pay more for your favorite chocolate?

Kenyan police move to end the siege on an upscale Nairobi mall, now in its third day, with more than 68 people confirmed dead. http://on.wsj.com/1ahG9jN

"They were at all the exits; even if you wanted to escape you couldn't," one witness said.
Ever wondered where the cheapest—and most expensive—place to buy an iPad is? Here's a list: http://on.wsj.com/1dCBY3O

Typhoon Usagi hit southern China, killing at least 25 people, but the full brunt of the storm skirted Hong Kong, which had expected to take a direct hit. http://on.wsj.com/16As1z1
 
Photos of the killer typhoon: http://on.wsj.com/18NVACY
Credit: Chance Chan/Reuters

Former Communist Party official Bo Xilai was sentenced to life in prison by a Chinese court after being convicted of bribery, embezzlement and abuse of power. http://on.wsj.com/16kzuYC

Despite the end to China's most politically charged trial in decades, the Communist Party remains split over Mr. Bo's policies. http://on.wsj.com/15NK1cu

What do you think about the outcome and sentencing?

Credit: European Pressphoto Agency
If it were anyone else, Wall Street would probably laugh him off. But because it's Jeremy Grantham, they just might listen.

Big pay-TV operators including Comcast and Verizon's FiOS are taking steps to vastly expand their on-demand TV offerings, edging toward turf occupied by online players like Netflix. 
http://on.wsj.com/14uvu4t

Gunmen burst into an upscale shopping mall in Nairobi, opening fire and throwing grenades in a terrorist attack that has left at least 39 dead and more than 150 injured. http://on.wsj.com/1eyoJo2

Photo: An image taken from AFP TV shows a woman coming out of an air vent where she had been hiding. (Nichole Sobecki/AFP/Getty Images)

One-fifth of U.S. states won't return to pre-recession employment levels until 2016 or later, economists say. http://on.wsj.com/1gLBIPZ

Michigan, Rhode Island and Nevada likely won’t return to peak employment until 2018 — more than one decade since the Great Recession began.

One of the most agonizing questions that parents of children with autism ask is-why? Now, a growing number of genetic tests are providing some answers. http://on.wsj.com/QfvZse

At Mount Sinai School of Medicine's Seaver Autism Center, Lisa Edelmann, director of genetic testing, and Alex Kolevzon, clinical director, lead an effort to test for autism-related gene mutations.

Facebook on Monday denied reports of a system bug that supposedly exposed private messages on users' Timeline. The social networking company said the messages were, in fact, older wall posts that were already public. What were your first thoughts when you heard about the so-called Facebook bug?

This fall, Colorado, Oregon and Washington will consider state ballot measures to legalize pot.

The initiatives underscore how public attitudes about marijuana have evolved. Last year, a Gallup poll found 50% of Americans favored legalizing the drug. When Gallup began asking the question in 1969, only 12% did. 

What do you think about legalizing marijuana?

Guilty pleas resolved 97% of all federal cases last year, up from 84% in 1990. http://on.wsj.com/QQo2r4 

A growing number of federal defendants plead guilty, often to avoid the lengthy prison sentences that can come with losing at trial. This relentless growth in plea bargaining has sparked a backlash among lawyers, legal scholars and judges.

College students are now permitted to carry guns on public campuses in five states, four more than two years ago. 
 
"It is not a force field, but it just means that if something bad does happen, we can fight back," said Ken Stanton, who chose Colorado State because he could carry a gun there.
 
What do you think about college students being allowed to carry guns on campus?

Why your so-called free checking account is more expensive than ever: http://on.wsj.com/QdWu1g

U.S. bank customers must now keep an average minimum balance of $723 in their checking accounts to avoid paying a monthly fee. That's up 365% from 2007, when balances could be below $200. 

Is your bank pressuring you for a higher balance? Have you encountered more banking fees?

Are stars today less glamorous than in Hollywood's past?  A new book examines the mythology of celebrity, how it was once manufactured and how the star system has changed in the modern era, when it's so possible to poke holes and find fault via social media.

Got a great tech idea? Compete for Y Combinator's prestigious boot camp.  http://on.wsj.com/QcRNol

A new book takes us behind the scenes as thousands of ideas are vetted and a few dozen backed by heavy venture capital and business development support. YC is the most high-profile of the incubators and accelerators: companies that breed other companies.  It's where Codeacademy and Dropbox came from.  

Illustration: Shaw Nielsen

Are driverless cars our future?  http://on.wsj.com/QcOjSR

WSJ's automotive critic Dan Neal spent some time "manfully freaking out" as his driverless car careened around a raceway. His conclusion, "a robo-driver would certainly kick my butt."  He says the technology has long since passed the point of mere competence to arrive at expert status, and is certainly safer than humans behind the wheel. What do you think?

Illustration: C.J. Burton

Are we getting smarter as a species, as evidenced on IQ tests using challenges like the one pictured?  (Fill in the last shape.) http://on.wsj.com/QcMMwi 

Advanced nations like the U.S. have experienced massive IQ gains over time. From the early 1900s to today, Americans have gained three IQ points per decade on two different scales.  Intelligence expert and author James R. Flynn details how human mental abilities have grown in the modern era. It's a fascinating exploration of how we learn and adapt.  What do you think? Is each generation smarter than the last? 

Photo: An example of Raven's Progressive Matrices.

If medical errors were a disease, they would be the sixth leading cause of death in America - just behind accidents and ahead of Alzheimer's. Yet these mistakes go largely unnoticed.

The number of centenarians world-wide, now about a half million, has been increasing by about 7% a year. http://on.wsj.com/SLMoS1

What is it about centenarians' genes that increases their resistance to age-related illnesses? Scientists are competing in a $10 million challenge to quickly, cheaply and accurately sequence the genomes of 100 centenarians around the world.

President Barack Obama has opened an 8 percentage-point lead in Iowa and maintains a five-point edge in Colorado and Wisconsin, according to latest WSJ polls. http://on.wsj.com/SITjeu

Even if Mitt Romney won all the states in which Obama leads by less than 3 percentage points - such as Colorado, Florida and Iowa - Obama would still win re-election based on his leads in Ohio, Virginia and smaller swing states.

As Apple began selling the iPhone 5, it faced complaints over its mapping app, which replaces Google maps on its devices. http://on.wsj.com/Q22F8t

Criticism poured in as users found misplaced labels for landmarks, missing roads and erroneous features. A search for the Golden Gate Bridge yielded a marker roughly 4 miles away in San Francisco. Moving to a better neighborhood will make you healthier and happier:  http://on.wsj.com/SIeQE7

A new study tracked thousands of low-income families moving from impoverished areas to mixed-income neighborhoods. It found significantly lower rates of diabetes, obesity, and anxiety.

An elite runner still at 37, Bernard Lagat defies the corrosive effects of time - and avoids injury and burnout - by pigging out and kicking back when his season is over. "Rest is a good thing," he says. After this Saturday's race he will begin a couch-potato sabbatical until November. He anticipates gaining eight pounds, and calls it pure bliss.  

What do you think? Have you found benefits to extended training breaks?

Would you like a coffee table which is actually a periodic table? It's $8500. http://on.wsj.com/Ptg9IJ

Thanks in part to hit TV shows like "Breaking Bad" - the series about a teacher who cooks crystal meth to pay medical bills - chemistry is cool. You can buy shower curtains and coffee mugs. Videos celebrating chemistry log millions of views. It's all part of the "ascendancy of the nerd" these days. Are you a nerd?

The MGM Grand in Las Vegas is betting hotel rooms can help make you healthier with its new line of "Stay Well" rooms. But do the experts agree? http://on.wsj.com/SFwR5Y

Each "Stay Well" room or suite comes with special amenities like a vitamin C shower infuser and mini-bars stocked with oatmeal and coconut water.

Would you want to stay in one of these rooms? Do you think a hotel room can make you healthier?

World-wide, tourists are victimized by criminals at much higher rates than local residents. How to protect yourself against pickpockets: http://on.wsj.com/SENMWk

Creating diversions is a common tactic. A thief may squirt something on victims, drop coins in front of them or show them a map and ask for directions. Another tactic is for a fake police officer to demand to see your wallet, which is then swiped.

Have you ever had your wallet or purse stolen? What are your tips for protecting yourself?

Most meetings are unnecessary, take too long and get little accomplished, writes Robert C. Pozen, author of "Extreme Productivity."

So how do you make meetings more productive? One key is to limit their size by only inviting those employees who are vitally necessary. Studies show a smaller group (5 to 7) is more effective at decision-making. 

Most importantly, you should keep your meetings as short as possible. Meetings rarely need to last for more than one hour, and virtually never past 90 minutes.

Ordering a chocolate shake, fries and a burger at Shake Shack is just shy of 2,000 calories-the recommended adult caloric intake for an entire day. http://on.wsj.com/SEIGJQ

The fast food chain is now required to post calorie counts on menu boards in New York City, just like McDonald's and Starbucks. 

Does knowing the calorie count change what you would order?

The next step in the evolution of the luxury-car business: the rise of all-wheel drive. http://on.wsj.com/PUAQiw

Many industry executives say all-wheel drive is now a must-have technology for the U.S. market. "It's not even a debate," says Jim Vurpillat, global marketing director for Cadillac.

Cars that send power to all four wheels account for half or more of luxury-car sales in the colder parts of the U.S. and as much as 15% of sales in snow-free states.

The average full-time U.S. worker gets about 2.6 weeks of vacation a year but more than half don't use up their allotment. 

To remedy the problem, some companies are offering employees the chance to buy vacation days for the following year or sell off days from the current year.

If you could cash in your vacation time for more money, would you?

For super-fast traders, there's a way to jump ahead in line:
http://on.wsj.com/PTTpTQ

High-frequency traders sometimes use a special type of order to step in front of ordinary investors to buy and sell stocks. The maneuvers are executed in a fraction of a second, fueling concerns about whether the fastest traders gain unfair advantages.

Applications for full-time M.B.A. programs fell 22% worldwide in 2012. http://on.wsj.com/PsWU1D

Overall, 62% of U.S. schools reported declines in applications to two-year M.B.A. programs. This is the fourth year in a row that applications have declined.

Columbia Business School experienced one of the sharpest drops, posting a 19% decline.

Entering a field like banking, medicine or law once guaranteed a high salary and job security – but such assurances are quickly becoming a thing of the past.

The median pay for 2011 law grads in private practice was $85,000, down 35% from $130,000 in 2009.

General surgeons have seen their salaries drop by 12% since 2010, while ER doctors saw an 8% decline. Only 54% said they would choose medicine as a career again if they had the chance to start over.

A growing number of U.S. and Canadian soccer fans are performing what's known as 'tifo' - or giant, choreographed displays of support put on by hundreds of fans in the stands. They're spending thousands of dollars and countless hours to put on the showy moments. Photos: http://on.wsj.com/Pgkrmt

The U.S. ranked fourth-worst among 29 developed countries for children obtaining a higher level of education than their parents, according to an OECD report.

In the U.S. only 21.6% of those 25 to 34 years old achieved a higher level of education than their parents. That compares to the developed countries' average of 36.8%.

Americans with a college degree earn about three times more on average than those without a high school diploma, the OECD found.

Many American adults don't understand basic concepts of investing, a new survey shows.

For example, only 53% answered this question correctly: "True or false: Buying a single company's stock usually provides a safer return than a stock mutual fund."

6% got the answer wrong, choosing "True." But fully 40% said they didn't know the answer, and 1% declined to answer.

More than 1 in 4 American adults has a diagnosable mental-health disorder. http://on.wsj.com/SVP0Sq

Accommodations for employees with diagnosed mental illnesses may include offering flexible work hours, a leave of absence, allowing for weekly therapy sessions or reassigning them to a role with fewer deadlines.

Two workers, one computer. Programmers are pairing up on computers at Facebook and other tech companies.

With water in short supply across the country, some are calling for a drastic solution: drinking recycled sewage. http://on.wsj.com/SDQsbI

New research shows older fathers pass on more genetic mutations to their children than younger dads: http://on.wsj.com/NIiY6X

A 20-year-old dad passes on an average of 25 new genetic mutations to his child while a 40-year-old father transmits about 65, says a new study published in the journal Nature. 

Kari Stefansson, the study's lead author, said it is “very likely that the rise in the mean age of fathers” has contributed to the rise of autism.

The summer’s heat waves have brought some good news: a low number of tornadoes. http://on.wsj.com/NeHJfw

Last month, the warmest month on record for the U.S., was also the quietest July ever for tornadoes. Just 24 twisters were recorded in the U.S., shattering the previous low of 73 in July 1960.

What do you think about this summer's unusual weather pattern?

Nike is expected to debut its most expensive shoe yet, a $315 Lebron James sneaker: http://on.wsj.com/ShInb1

Adjusted for inflation, Nike's Lebron line has more than doubled in price since 2008. Overall, basketball shoe prices are up 9.4% from a year ago.

What do you think of the rising price of athletic shoes? What's the most you've paid for a sneaker?

Lincoln Center in New York City was the setting for Le Diner En Blanc: http://on.wsj.com/O1Qyr5

The invitation-only pop-up picnic required guests to wear all white. The picnic's location was kept secret until shortly before the event. Pop-up picnics will also be staged in Philadelphia on Thursday, Chicago on Friday, and next week in Vancouver, Singapore and Brisbane, Australia, followed by about a dozen other cities months from now.

Photo: Natalie Keyssar for The Wall Street Journal

When your body has grown into adulthood, researchers now say your brain has not. http://on.wsj.com/QW6ZBX

Many parents of 20-somethings worry that their offspring haven't yet found a career path, gotten married or become financially independent. These parents should chill out, experts say, as latest research suggests the late 20s are when many of us become best equipped to make major life decisions.   

What do you think? Did you get more serious in your late 20s after an extended adolescence?  Does this help explain slackers you know?

Apple is now the most valuable company of all time, surpassing Microsoft's previous record set in December 1999. http://on.wsj.com/PAkn1U

The stock gained 2.6% to close at $665.15 Monday, giving Apple a market value of $623.5 billion, according to FactSet data. Many analysts think Apple shares will continue to climb.

Will the next election be hacked? http://on.wsj.com/RcjvBD

Online voting is on the rise, but some experts see it as a nightmare for the integrity of the electoral process, writes Michael Agresta. 

In all, 31 states will offer some form of online voting this fall, usually for overseas voters.

Illustration: Oliver Munday

Comedienne Phyllis Diller died at the age of 95 in Los Angeles. http://on.wsj.com/QTDil1

Here is a look back at some of her wittiest lines: http://on.wsj.com/NYGsr8. 

What are some of your fondest memories of Ms. Diller?

Photo: Everett Collection
What are your thoughts on Augusta National admitting female members?

Iguanas now outnumber humans in Puerto Rico: http://on.wsj.com/OsSEiq

The U.S. territory tried declaring iguanas a nuisance, opening the way for people to hunt them. But that didn't put much of a dent in the population. Now, authorities have a new solution: eat them.

Puerto Rico hopes to gather iguanas up, slaughter them and export the meat to countries in Latin America, Asia and elsewhere with a taste for the lizards.

Photo: José Jiménez-Tirado for The Wall Street Journal
The Miss World pageant finalist from the Philippines surprised the audience, who might have been expecting baton twirling.  Her performance has since gone viral. http://on.wsj.com/RwineB

Kickstarter has exploded. Explore some of the best and worst inventions funded by folks like you:  http://on.wsj.com/TPx8qh

The crowdsourcing website has grown from a wacky platform four years ago designed to help inventors fund their dreams to a backer of multi-million-dollar hits. Is it just modern-day panhandling? Is it too risky for you? Or are you tempted by ground-floor access to the next Loomi or Twig?

Illustration: James Yang for The Wall Street Journal

Rep. Todd Akin says his "off the cuff" remarks do not reflect his "deep empathy...for the thousands of women who are raped and abused every year."  His opponent, Sen. Claire McCaskill, says "It is beyond comprehension that someone can be so ignorant about the emotional and physical trauma brought on by rape."

Between 2000 and 2010, 165,068 people were killed in the U.S. (not including Florida).   http://on.wsj.com/NTKoJE

How many victims and killers were related? How many were neighbors? How often were drugs and alcohol involved? You can look over the circumstances, weapons, locations, victims, and killers in our interactive database of FBI and Justice Department data.

U.S. murder rates are declining but that trend masks a grim and underreported truth: the persistently high rate at which young black men are killing one other. 
http://on.wsj.com/OoX5e1

According to data kept by the Justice Department and FBI,  more than half the nation's homicide victims are African-American, though blacks make up only 13% of the population. Of those black murder victims, 85% were men, mostly young men.

Even outside, second-hand smoke poses a health risk. http://on.wsj.com/NMYKeO

In one study, nonsmokers who visited outdoor restaurants and bars where smoking was allowed had elevated levels of tobacco-related chemicals in their bodies after just three hours.

Illustration: Kelly Alder

"It is remarkable that so much attention has been given to the radioactive release from Fukushima, considering that the direct death and destruction from the tsunami was enormously greater." http://on.wsj.com/NNPAid

Should the Fukushima accident in Japan be used as a reason for putting an end to nuclear power? In our Saturday Essay, Dr. Richard Muller argues against it.

In search of a vacation destination? Take Monday off and say oui to a trip to Quebec City, where cobblestone streets and mansard roofs co-exist happily with modern architecture and a thriving food scene. http://on.wsj.com/QKjYGR

Photo: Will Lew for The Wall Street Journal

The Securities & Exchange Commission charged Hall of Famer Eddie Murray with insider trading, alleging he made about $235,314 in illegal profits. http://on.wsj.com/N9pylq

Mr. Murray agreed to settle the SEC’s charges without admitting or denying the allegations.

The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, known as Darpa, is preparing to assess whether crowdsourcing, a freewheeling collaborative method, can be an effective means of designing military equipment.

The U.S. military is hoping tapping volunteers will counter the high costs and delays that often dog the development of new weaponry and vehicles.

What do you think of the military crowdsourcing its designs? Will it help lower expenses or could it lead to a potential security risk?

Facebook's stock price plummeted to a new low, as early investors were freed to sell some of their stakes:
http://on.wsj.com/QJxQBe

The stock is down nearly 50% from its debut. Facebook's market cap has fallen from $104.8 billion three months ago to $48 billion today.

Do you think Facebook's stock will continue to fall? What are your predictions about the company's future?

This week, eBay started testing a same-day service that aims to deliver packages in about an hour. For $5 an order, customers can order items from partners like Target and Best Buy and have them arrive as fast as a pizza.

How much of your shopping do you do online? Would you buy more online if packages arrived quickly?

An analyst estimates cybercrime cost the financial-services industry $2.5 billion last year. http://on.wsj.com/NJ5etg

More banks are paying to snatch up exclusive new Internet addresses to crack down on crime, such as dot-citi or dot-barclays.  Have you been phished or scammed? Did you lose a lot, and did your bank help?

Illustration: Mikey Burton for The Wall Street Journal
How many years of tax returns should presidential candidates release? http://on.wsj.com/NMzsd7

New details have emerged on Apple's TV vision: http://on.wsj.com/NJvpBZ

Among the new features of Apple's proposed new set-top box: A smoother user interface, possibly employing the rows of icons used in the iPad, and social media features, such as ways to share TV shows through outlets like Twitter.

Developers around the country are betting big on skyscrapers, building residential buildings at record-breaking heights. http://on.wsj.com/OnXpHc

Changing the skyline in New York, London and Dallas, the tallest new residences will stretch over 90 stories, with at least one penthouse asking over $100 million. Photo gallery: http://on.wsj.com/OnXyKA 

Photo: Adam Friedberg for The Wall Street Journal

"Iran’s Ministry of Communications and Technology has announced the launch of a domestic intranet — a completely closed loop that would leave Iranian citizens without online access to the rest of the world." http://on.mktw.net/R5e1sk

But what would this mean for a country like Iran? Can a nation simply flip a switch and disconnect itself from the Web?

Researchers from Harvard University have encoded an entire book into actual DNA.

In that form, a billion copies of the book could fit in a test tube. "If you wanted to have your library encoded in DNA, you could probably do that now,” said Drew Endy, a synthetic biologist.

What do you think of using DNA to store things like books, poetry and music?

Japan's once-mighty electronics giants have missed the smartphone wave: http://on.wsj.com/OlrjvP

Apple and Samsung are enjoying record profits and are combining for some 54% of global smartphone shipments in the first quarter. The combined share for Sony, Panasonic, Sharp and other Japanese manufacturers: 8%.

What do you think of this change? Who makes your smartphone?

Companies are betting that customers will soon be as comfortable paying with their smartphones as with their credit cards. Wal-Mart, Target and other companies are joining forces to develop a mobile wallet system.

Mobile payments are expected to quadruple to $600 billion world-wide by 2016, according to Gartner Inc.

What do you think of paying with your smartphone? Are you comfortable doing it?

Didn't get a raise this year? Blame inflation: http://sm.wsj.com/THnOER

Wages typically track inflation, soaring higher when prices take off. Now companies have less pressure to raise wages.

“What companies are looking at is, what do they have to pay you to keep you from quitting your job?” said John Lonski, an economist with Moody’s Capital Markets.
Ecuador says that Julian Assange faces a real threat of political persecution and even the death penalty if the U.K. hands him over to the U.S.  What do you think?
Csanad Szegedi asks for forgiveness, says he does not regret discovering his Jewish ancestry, despite the anti-Semitic views which defined his political career.

Tens of thousands of young illegal immigrants across the country applied Wednesday to a program that could allow them to remain in the country and work legally. http://on.wsj.com/OxMjFj

What do you think of the new immigration policy?

Social media, design apps and shopping sites are helping freshman college students share ideas and deck out their dorm rooms from afar -- in some cases, even before they've met their roommates. http://on.wsj.com/NEuIda

Photo: Rebecca Greenfield for The Wall Street Journal

Cities are making big bets to revitalize their downtowns by bringing back the streetcar: http://on.wsj.com/NBWNzY

Some cities are counting on help from federal stimulus dollars, but a few are going it alone. Late last month, about 500 residents in one part of Kansas City, Mo., voted to create a special taxing district to raise $75 million over about two decades for a streetcar.

Will streetcars boost economic growth or are they a waste of tax dollars?

Photo: Carl Kiilsgaard for The Wall Street Journal

See your state’s voter-ID requirements with this interactive state-by-state breakdown: http://on.wsj.com/QCoNlu

Thirty states have laws in place that will require voters to show ID before voting in November, up from 24 states four years ago, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.

What do you think about voter-identification laws?

Facebook is lagging behind competitors in the battle for ad dollars: http://on.wsj.com/NF8q7u

Google is dominating the online-ad market. Last year, it made 4X as much in ad dollars as Yahoo, and almost 8X as much as Facebook. Several companies complained it's difficult to gauge the ROI from Facebook likes and ads.

What are your predictions about the future of Facebook? Do you think it's an effective business model?

The Olympics are over, which means it's a great time to go to London: http://sm.wsj.com/Nmhejn

Hotel room rates for late August and September are down about 60% compared to this time last year. Some hotels are also throwing in extras like free breakfasts and room upgrades.

Photo: Shutterstock.com

In the '80s, only 36% of adoptions were open. Today, it's 95%. http://on.wsj.com/QBGemb

Have you had experience with open adoptions? Do the benefits outweigh the complications?  Does it confuse or help children? Should information about birthparents wait until the children reach a certain age? 

Katy Katzenbach, second from right, at the June 2008 wedding of her birth mother, Jennifer Peterson Bordean, second from left. They are joined by Ms. Katzenbach's adoptive mom, Sue, far right, and her birth grandmother, Nancy, far left.

Is your boss a screamer? http://on.wsj.com/PYx9TW

Research has shown it makes the target of the anger less effective, and could lead to lawsuits or YouTube ridicule.  But there's still plenty of conflict in many workplaces, just channeled differently. 

You can learn about ways to deal with a screamer, or to find safer ways to vent your own office anger, in our live chat today at 2:30 p.m. ET. http://on.wsj.com/RPiT4E

To relieve stress and exercise, Jean K. Reilly, 46, took up sky diving. http://on.wsj.com/MYcQM3

Why not just yoga or meditation? "When you're doing yoga, you can still think about other things," she says. "When you're falling through the air at 100 miles per hour, you have to be focused."

In geek news: The U.S. Census Bureau population clock rolled past 314,159,265, or the equivalent of 100 million times Pi (3.14159265), Tuesday. http://on.mktw.net/PVTi5k

The National Institutes of Health estimates 79 million U.S. adults – or 1 in 3 - have prediabetes. 

About 26 million Americans have Type 2 diabetes, including 7 million who may have Type 2 diabetes and not know it.

What do you think about this growing public health threat? Has diabetes affected you or your family?

Nearly two-thirds of U.S. teenagers say they use YouTube to listen to music: http://on.wsj.com/R0lFUP

Among adults, the most popular ways to listen to music are on the radio and CDs. YouTube came in third.

How do you listen to music? Have you noticed a generation gap emerge over how people listen to music?

Are procrastinators truly unproductive? In most cases, the exact opposite is true.

They don't have neat desks or even neat desktops on their laptops. They spend a lot of time playing catch-up. Here are some tips on the art of procrastination.

Are you a procrastinator? What do you do when you're avoiding the task at hand?

Tuition is soaring at state schools: http://sm.wsj.com/OrjA4S

The cost of attending California's public colleges has doubled in the past five years. In Georgia, Arizona and Washington, tuition and fees have risen more than 15% just in the past year.

What do you think of the rising cost of a public education?

Has Facebook made us all braggarts? http://on.wsj.com/MWQlqV

Most of us craft our social media updates to be pithy, witty, just generally to reflect well on us. How do you feel about status updates that humble-brag? Do you think they can hurt how we're seen by others and even damage our relationships?

The U.S. military is joining with border-patrol officials in a new initiative that could bring dozens of surveillance blimps from the battlefields of Afghanistan to America's border with Mexico.

Share your favorite moments from the London Games.

Our new 360-degree panorama from NASA's Curiosity rover, taken on Aug. 9, shows the area around the rover within Gale Crater on Mars -- all in color.

Like the black-and-white version more? That's still available as well.

A California city is considering taxing businesses on the sugary drinks they sell: http://on.wsj.com/Nu6j84

Richmond, Calif. has a measure on its November ballot to charge businesses a penny for every ounce of sweetened beverages they sell in the city. If it passes, it would be the first city tax of its kind in the nation and the first to be approved by voters.

What do you think of this tax? Is it unfair to businesses or does it help encourage healthier eating and drinking habits?

Disagreeing with your boss may actually help your career.

Career advisers say making effective arguments can help you gain your manager's respect and increase your chances of being promoted. (But choose your battles wisely and remain civil.)

How do you handle disagreements with your boss?

Planning on getting the new iPhone? You may want to sell your current iPhone now: http://sm.wsj.com/Mn3asW

Resale prices are peaking. Right now, Gazelle will pay $270, NextWorth offers $263 and Amazon Trade-In prices go up to $290 for a 16-gig iPhone 4S. Prices are expected to drop 20% to 25% closer to the new iPhone's release date.

Are you planning to get the new iPhone? What's your smartphone of choice?

Should inheritances be contingent on drug testing? http://on.wsj.com/MTi23S

What about requiring college graduation? Remaining a stay-at-home parent?  How about disinheriting you if you challenge the will in court? Yes, one can, in effect, control heirs from the grave.

One firm estimated Apple's brand is worth $183 billion, while another said $33.5 billion. IKEA recently disclosed it values its brand at $11 billion.

Dreaming about a vacation? It may pay to go after Labor Day: http://sm.wsj.com/MYXx17

Usain Bolt battles his fellow Jamaican Yohan Blake for gold in the men's 200-meter final.  We replay the action ... with clothespins puppets. Our latest episode of homemade highlights: http://on.wsj.com/MlS9Ij

#homemadehighlights

Usain Bolt won the 200-meter final to become the first man to twice win the 100-meter and 200-meter Olympic races.  http://on.wsj.com/MDDFVy

The Jamaicans swept the field in the race. Mr. Bolt finished in 19.32 seconds, while his teammates, Yohan Blake and Warren Weir, took second and third, respectively.

U.S. gymnast McKayla Maroney is not impressed by this Olympic meme: http://on.wsj.com/NgQ6VE

When Maroney lost the gold in the vault competition, she stood on the podium with a scowl on her face. She looked thoroughly ... unimpressed.

July was the hottest month in the contiguous U.S. since records began in 1895: http://on.wsj.com/NlXhtP

Temperatures during July averaged 77.6 degrees -- 3.3 degrees warmer than the 20th-century average. The previous warmest July was in 1936, at the height of the Dust Bowl, when the average temperature was 77.4 degrees.

Did last month seem unusually warm to you? How did you beat the heat?

Cable and satellite companies lost 418,000 paying TV customers last quarter: http://sm.wsj.com/NpPABf

SmartMoney reporter Kelli Grant saved $60 a month by cutting the cord and relying on streaming options like Hulu Plus. She shares her tips.

Have you cut the cord, or would you? What do you think of the experience?

Looking for a recession-proof business? Consider opening a tattoo parlor. http://on.wsj.com/O6Yd8S

Some artists in Williamsburg, Brooklyn are making up to $200 per hour, and are booked 3 months out.

Your patriotic duty in Singapore - make a baby today. http://on.wsj.com/S4rCx1 

A campaign behind the August 9 independence celebration asks Sinaporeans to help solve the city-state's low birthrate.  A rap video drives the message home, "you gotta do what you gotta do, baby."

Our Dennis K. Berman read and sifted through some 500 earnings call transcripts and found a surprising number: At least 35 CEOs publicly vented about Washington. 

What do you make of their remarks?

Scientists have used nanotechnology materials to repair vital tissues damaged in heart attacks, suggesting a new way to treat heart failure in people. http://on.wsj.com/QMH1Hm

The World Health Organization estimates that more than 17 million people died from cardiovascular diseases in 2008. In the U.S., about 785,000 people will have new heart attacks this year and 470,000 will suffer recurrent ones.

The unemployment rate is higher under Barack Obama than for any president seeking re-election since FDR: http://on.wsj.com/MwlEm8

Obama says he inherited a bad economy from Republicans, and it will take time to heal. Mitt Romney says Obama made matters worse.

What impact do you think unemployment will have on the election? Who do you think will win?

Training for the Olympics can cripple a family's finances. Swimmer Ryan Lochte's divorced parents are facing foreclosure on their Florida home. Gymnast Gabby Douglas's mother filed for bankruptcy earlier this year.

By some estimates, it can cost $250,000 for a decade of training and competing - with no guaranteed payoff.

Do you think going for the gold is worth the cost? Why or why not?

Who cries the most at the Olympics? http://on.wsj.com/O4Rf1t

The answer: Women cry more than men, 25% compared to 8%, but many of the men who did cry seriously lost it.

Are you better off today than you were four years ago? Ronald Reagan's famous question to voters in his 1980 campaign now looms over the 2012 presidential election. http://on.wsj.com/O4CDPx

Over several weeks this summer, Wall Street Journal reporter Rachel Emma Silverman used a robot to remotely roam the Journal's newsroom from her home office in Austin, Texas. http://on.wsj.com/Ni3wyB

"The robot made me feel closer to distant colleagues," she writes. But is "botting" the future of work?

More than 1 in 10 adults globally are affected by migraines, which can be incapacitating, according to the World Health Organization. The hunt is intensifying for new treatments:  http://on.wsj.com/MuQKkc

The pay-TV industry lost about 400,000 subscribers in the second quarter, the latest sign that cord-cutting, or dropping pay-TV in favor of online options, may be under way. http://on.wsj.com/NhRd5E

New telemedicine websites link people to a licensed doctor via phone or video chat: http://on.wsj.com/OX1Oog

Playing a musical instrument could make you smarter and improve your memory: http://sm.wsj.com/MhIF0S

Adults ages 59 to 80 who played an instrument when they were younger performed better on memory tests and cognitive ability. Music appeared to enhance reasoning skills and counteract the effects of aging.

More than 70% of all drowning deaths in the U.S. each year involve adults.  Nearly 40% of all adults can't swim across a pool. It takes most adults about three months to learn to swim, and more clinics are adding specialized classes to lure grownups into the pool. http://on.wsj.com/QARdk5

Nigerian scammers know their ploys are obvious and that most of us won't fall for them. But some experts say we absolutely should respond, and that by doing so, we can help defeat them by wasting the scammers' time.  http://on.wsj.com/N8V2Mi

Sticking to a diet may be much more difficult than quitting smoking. Behavioral economist Dan Ariely explains why:
http://on.wsj.com/RGu6S5

Short-term considerations tend to override our best intentions. So while we may say we'll only eat 1 or 2 desserts a month, our priorities change when the dessert tray comes out and we see triple-chocolate cake.

America's two largest teachers unions have stepped up spending on politics and lobbying efforts in recent years. 

A look at their more than $330 million in contributions over the past five years on political activities and advocacy work that has helped give teachers widespread political clout on Capitol Hill and in statehouses: http://on.wsj.com/MoqZeK

With full seasons of TV shows streaming online at places like Netflix and Hulu, or on-demand from cable providers, how is so called "binge viewing" - watching entire seasons in a matter of days - affecting show creators? Will they re-think how they pace the story arc, or how they deal with episode-ending cliff hangers? 

Some show creators fear viewers will miss some of the show's nuance by watching it all at once - instead of having a week for it to sink in between episodes. 

Have you ever "binged" on an entire TV series or season? Did you feel like you missed out on anything by watching it so quickly?

More than $2 million dollars was spent on one of Medicare's most expensive cases in 2009 - and the patient did not live.  A small percentage of challenging cases, often at the end of life, make up the great bulk of Medicare spending. Why are hairdressers so secure? It's because their jobs - along with others in the personal-service industry such as fast-food workers and home health-aides - aren't easily automated or outsourced.  

Between 2007 and 2010, the total number of jobs in the U.S. fell by nearly 6%. The number of middle-skill jobs, those most susceptible to automation or offshoring, fell by 12%. But despite the recession, there was a 2% increase in personal-service jobs. http://on.wsj.com/LVPGPp

The fall of Bo Xilai, once a rising star in Chinese politics, has plunged the country into its biggest political crisis since Tiananmen Square. It upset the Communist Party's carefully crafted succession plans and strained relations with the U.K. and U.S.

Take Amazon reviews with a grain of salt, a study says. Of the top Amazon reviews, more than 80% were positive. The study found that 85% of the site's most prolific reviewers received free products from publishers, agents, authors and manufacturers.
