How often do you buy products on Amazon? Do you prefer shopping in person or online?

The Supreme Court upheld a key part of Arizona's immigration law, while striking down other parts. 

The court backed a section of the Arizona state law that calls for police to check the immigration status of people they stop.

It struck down three other provisions: making it a crime for immigrants without work permits to seek employment; making it a crime for immigrants to fail to carry work permits; and authorizing police to arrest any immigrant they believe has committed a deportable offense.

What are your thoughts on the Supreme Court's ruling?

Thousands of heads of state, diplomats, political experts, foreign correspondents and activists use Twitter.  A new 'e-diplomacy hub' allows you to keep track of what they are talking about.  

Do you follow any politicians, heads of state, diplomats or journalists directly through social media?  How has being able to interact with them changed your view of what they do?
How did the U.N. find itself in the middle of one of the world's bloodiest and most unmanageable conflicts? And why are its troops picking sides? Our Saturday Essay:

Entrepreneurs and big companies are battling one another for the rights to manage hot new Web address endings. Among the most popular: .app, .home and .book.

What do you think of these new right-of-the-dot names?

"To most of its users, Facebook seemed to come from nowhere; to me, it had meant long and sometimes very exciting hours—and some difficult experiences that didn't belong on my Facebook 'wall.' "

An early Facebook staffer recalls the raucous days of a company in transition from Harvard dorm room to Silicon Valley.
Lenders are pushing a new product: a student loan that borrowers start paying off while they still are in school. But is the new loan option worth it?
The ruling next week will have a profound impact on Americans.  The justices may uphold the health-care law, strike down part of it or toss it all out. Which outcome are you hoping for, and why?

On average, Americans spent 2.75 hours watching TV each day and 8.7 hours sleeping.

This interactive graphic lets you plug in in the number of hours you spend doing each activity (working, sleeping, eating) to see how your typical day stacks up to the average American's.

How does your schedule compare? Are you surprised by any of the results?

The average ticket for a Justin Bieber concert now sells for $376. That's down from a peak of $439 a week ago.

For the top concert tours last year, the average ticket's face value was $67, up 9% from 2010. But it's possible to get summer tickets for much less. Here's how: http://sm.wsj.com/NoIfVo

Before the financial crisis, investors viewed the biggest U.S. banks as essentially risk-free. Watch that risk change dramatically since 2007 in this interactive graphic. 

What do you think about the stability of our financial system, with the latest Moody's downgrade of major banks and the constant red flags coming from Europe? Have you become a more risk-averse investor?

More job-seekers are looking for work-life balance: 18% this year, compared to 15% last year. “When the alterative was losing your job, people were happy to work longer hours. People are now saying they need balance,” says a CareerBuilder expert.  

Has the pendulum shifted for you? Did you work like a dog during the recession and now might you be able to dial that back a bit? Or do you have yet to recover from the recession? Have you shifted your work habits permanently?

In a nod to Asian buyers, the developers of one building put many of its most luxurious full-floor apartments on the 80th through 88th floors—a clever way to appeal to the Chinese belief that eight is the luckiest number. Apartment 88 is under contract to a Chinese buyer for around $50 million.  What do you think of such considerations in real estate. Is the portent, placement and energy of a space valuable enough to pay a premium?

Moody's downgraded five U.S. banks, including Morgan Stanley which saw its long-term rating cut by two notches. 

A look at the downgrades and the impact the banks said it would have:

Nevada has led the nation in unemployment for 27 months, taking the mantle from Michigan, which had the nation’s worst unemployment rate for 47 months from April 2006 to February 2010. 

Here's a breakdown of the states with the highest jobless rate in the country since 1976: http://on.wsj.com/MmE0t9

Did you participate in Facebook’s IPO? If so, what have you learned from the experience over the past month? Has it changed what you might do with future IPO opportunities?

Share your account.

The rising costs of higher education, the burden of student loans and a less-certain job market have left many wondering: Is college necessary? Is it a good investment? 

Four education-policy experts debate whether a lot of students would be better off spending their time and money somewhere else.

The No. 1 complaint among American workers? Offices that are freezing in the summer, and sweltering in the winter. http://on.wsj.com/MNucV6

Reporter Kelli Grant hosts a segment about how to deal with frigid indoor temperatures - even during the hottest days of summer.

What do you think of the temperature at your workplace?

Banks are going to great lengths to upsell to the 1%. U.S. Bank hosted a private fashion show at the Plaza Hotel for 300 of its wealthiest customers. On the guest list: credit-card customers who charge at least $50,000 annually and live in high-income ZIP codes.

Meanwhile, PNC Bank invited its wealthy clients to a private artwork viewing that included Picasso and Van Gogh paintings.

What do you think of these tactics?

To mark the change of season, the 10th annual “Solstice in Times Square” yoga class drew 4,000 participants.

http://on.wsj.com/LiNqHK

Photo by Katherine Rosman/The Wall Street Journal

The partisan divide over "Fast and Furious," holding the attorney general in contempt of Congress, and the president's use of executive privilege to shield documents is dividing our readers. 

What do you think? Is it happening because it's an election year? How will it affect the presidential race? Should Eric Holder be held in contempt? And did the president overstep by invoking the privilege?

The anti-social network? Research shows 25% of global companies don't allow customers to post questions or feedback on Facebook. 

Have you ever made a complaint or posted a question on a company's Facebook page? What response did you get? Would your view of a company or brand change if you found that they only used social media for one way communication?

"Merkel get ready, it's your turn now," Greek fans chanted on the streets of Athens over the weekend after Greece knocked Russia out of the tournament.

Meanwhile in Germany, the mass-circulation tabloid Bild said "Poor Greeks, we'll drive you bust again."

Are you ready? A euro zone grudge match is headed our way at soccer's European Championship:

At some of the country's most selective colleges, one study has shown, having an alum parent boosts the applicant's probability of acceptance by 45 percentage points.

Should colleges give weight to legacies in the admissions process? A proponent and a critic both weigh in on the debate. Who do you agree with?

J.C. Penney’s bold experiment with "honest" pricing didn't last long. The chain curbed clearance sales, while marking down everyday prices of items. The idea backfired. Sales fell 20% in the first quarter.

Retail experts say it's because shoppers love finding bargains - even if the original prices are inflated.

Do you think this is true? What did you think of J.C. Penney's strategy?

The list includes the Winkelvoss twins from "The Social Network" fame and gymnast Shawn Johnson. It could also extend to stars like Michael Phelps and Nastia Liukin. 

Tell us which M.I.A. athletes you had hoped to see at the 2012 Olympics. And which Olympians you are glad to see made it to London.

The Fed extended the "Operation Twist" program shifting holdings to longer-term securities through end of year. The central bank stopped short, however, of immediately taking the more aggressive step of launching a new bond-buying program to bolster the U.S. economic recovery.

The secret to living a long life: sleep. 71% of Americans who are 100 or older said they get at least 8 hours of sleep each night. By contrast, only 38% of baby boomers say they get that much rest.

What do you think of these findings? How much sleep do you get on average?

There's one area where it pays to procrastinate: buying a computer. Last year, laptop prices in August were 13% cheaper than in June.

Retailers are trying to lure students early this year. Apple gives Mac buyers a $100 gift card, while Best Buy offers a free Xbox for students who spend at least $699 on a Windows laptop.

Are you thinking about buying a new computer? Would you prefer a Mac or a PC?

Companies are flattening their hierarchies, giving workers the right to vote on each other's pay. At Valve, for example, there are no promotions, just new projects created by workers who recruit colleagues to help.  While less efficient up front, advocates say it's nimble, market-driven and a great way to run a company. What do you think?  Would you like to work like this?

Samsung hopes focusing on a universal smartphone design for all carriers will make it easier on consumers to pick Android phones over Apple's.

What do you think? Have you been confused by the variety of choices on the Android side? Or is that variety actually one of Android's strengths over the one-size-fits-all iPhone? Does the Galaxy S III look like a good flagship design for Samsung?

Many managers say bad grammar can create bad impressions with clients, ruin marketing materials and cause communications errors.

Do you think texting and social networking has caused an erosion in the use of proper grammar at the office? Share your office tales of grammar gaffes.

Mitt Romney said Tuesday that Sen. Marco Rubio is “being thoroughly vetted” as part of his vice presidential selection process, dismissing an earlier report that the first-term Florida Republican wasn’t being considered as his running mate.

What do you think of a Romney-Rubio ticket? Will Rubio's stance on immigration prevent him from becoming a running mate?
Half of Asians have a college degree, compared with 30% for all Americans, and their median annual household income is $66,000, versus $49,000 for Americans as a whole, according to a new report.

Mike Tyson is coming to Broadway. His one-man show-- "Mike Tyson: Undisputed Truth"--will be directed by Spike Lee, right, who joined Tyson on stage for a promotional event at the Longacre Theater. 

"I'm just naked and very vulnerable, and telling you who I am, and where I'm from," Tyson said of his show. "How this happened, and how I lost all this damn money, and how I had all these children and I go to prison and…you know. You know what happened, guys." http://on.wsj.com/L1rlag

What do you think of Mike Tyson going to Broadway? Do you want to see the show?

Photo by Rob Bennett for The Wall Street Journal.

Having a less-than-perfect credit score can get expensive. Poor credit scores disqualify almost half of Americans from record-low interest rates. They end up paying a high premium when applying for credit cards, mortgages and car loans.

Having an excellent credit score could save you tens of thousands of dollars a year. How's your credit score? What kind of impact has it had on your life?

There are two reasons to keep expectations low for the Microsoft Surface tablet, writes columnist Jack Hough. They’re called Zune and Kin, Microsoft’s 2006 MP3 player and 2010 phone, both of which flopped.

But even if you're underwhelmed with Microsoft's new tablet, you might still want to buy the company's stock. Here's why.

Do you think Microsoft is a good investment? What do you think of the Surface?

The new Surface is about the same size and weight as the iPad and will be comparable in price, says Steve Ballmer.  Does Microsoft have a shot at competing with iPad in the tablet space? Will you buy the Surface? How would you like to see tablet computers evolve?

Of those who report being unhappy in their marriages, 11.5% say it's due to a lack of personal space or privacy. That's more than the 6% who say their sex life is to blame.  

What is your experience? Have you had to carve out time away from your partner to keep the relationship strong? How do you do it without drifting apart? And what if you're in a relationship with someone who is too clingy?  Join our live chat today about this at 12 p.m. EDT.

Will it go wrong? What if l am not fully prepared? There's nothing like that feeling of worry before a big presentation. Well, it turns out a little bit of anxiety might make you perform at your best.

Do you think anxiety has helped you perform to your highest level? Has anxiety ever stopped you achieving something?
Microsoft is holding an event in Hollywood where it is expected to announce the first tablet computer under its own brand. Follow our live coverage and weigh in as we bring you the latest details:
A federal jury in Washington, D.C., found baseball great Roger Clemens not guilty of perjury and all other charges, rejecting prosecutors' allegations that he lied about steroid use.

Florida Sen. Marco Rubio said Monday that President Barack Obama’s move last week to block deportations for some young illegal immigrants in the U.S. has likely derailed his own similar efforts, at least until after the election. 

What do you think of the administration's new policy?
WSJ's Lee Hawkins sits down with the Kardashian Sisters for an exclusive interview about the business of celebrity and asks them: What do you do? What is your talent?

Nokia stock has collapsed by more than 90% since the summer of 2007. It announced 10,000 additional job cuts last week.

Its savior could be Microsoft. Nokia is ripe as a $10 billion-plus takeover target, writes Brett Arends. Both companies have been lagging in the mobile market behind iPhones and Android devices.

Do you think Nokia will ever bounce back? Would the company be a good investment for Microsoft?

The typical American divorce costs $15,000 to $30,000, with hourly rates ranging from $150 to $1,000.

The financial burden doesn't end there. Households with children in which parents were divorced for 6+ years faced a 40% to 45% average drop in family income. 

Divorced/separated mothers are also nearly 3X as likely as married mothers to end up in poverty.

News of Rodney King's passing is among our most popular stories. Police and community relations have improved in Los Angeles in recent decades, and crime has dropped sharply.  Surveys show a belief that race relations in LA have improved.  

What do you think? Was King's beating a turning point which began a trend toward better understanding and communication?

Another election in Greece puts a shaky government coalition in place with an austerity mandate, but so far the markets aren't euphoric. Are you on the sidelines, waiting for some clear signal that the euro zone is going to pull through? Or are you watching your portfolio take hits from the chaos? Join us today for insight into your next best moves.

Move over, Tiger Moms. In the beaten-down economies of Italy and Spain, the force to reckon with is the army of grandparents who form an invisible safety net helping young people make ends meet.

This week's Saturday Essay:

Is it okay to beat dad at sports on Father's Day? Nope, says Jason Gay. And he provides 10 rules to follow when going up against your pop. 

Have your own tips? Share them below.

President Obama is about to speak about a new policy on illegal immigrants.  Under new rules, people who came to the U.S. under the age of 16, who have not committed a major crime and who are still under the age of 30 will not be deported. They'll be eligible for a two-year deferral, during which they can apply for legal status.

What do you think? Does the policy encourage illegal immigration? Or is it a smart move to save taxpayer money and focus deportation efforts more productively?

The number of Twitter followers or Facebook friends you have could influence who you date, where you get hired and even your mortgage rates.

More companies are looking at Klout and other online influence scores when sizing up candidates for jobs or credit cards.

Do you think it makes sense to judge people by their influence online? Do you think you'd have a high, low or average score?

Rabbit ears are hot again, as more people cut their cable and satellite subscriptions. Every time Hulu and Netflix improve their service, antenna sales go up, says one retailer.

What are your must-see shows and how to you access them? Have your viewing habits changed?

Marissa Mayer of Google works 90-hour weeks, taking 60 meetings. She copes by having systems in place to accommodate her time away from the office.

What do you do when the pace of your work and home life tilt into the red zone?  How do you keep busy from becoming burnout?
The D: All Things Digital conference is coming up on June 1 http://allthingsd.com/d/ Here are dot drawings we've run of people who will be speaking at the conference.
The biggest share of the expense in raising a child is housing at 30%, followed by child-care and education at 18%, says new report.

Sales of high fashion, luxury cars and other top-flight goods are booming. Porsche sales in the U.S. jumped 15% last year. Imports of Swiss watches rocketed nearly 29% in the first quarter.

That's a good reason to invest in luxury companies. If you'd invested $1,000 in Ford stock 20 years ago, you'd have about $2,300 today. Porsche? Try $28,000.

What do you think of the rebound in sales of luxury goods?

Airlines are trying to prevent planes from arriving before gates are ready. They over-padded, to make sure flights would technically arrive on time, but that meant congestion on the ground. So now they're tweaking timetables again.

Have you wasted a lot of time waiting on board before a gate opens up?

Creators of the HBO series admit to using decapitated heads that resembled President Bush.  They say the heads were among prosthetic body parts they rent in bulk. They say they meant no disrespect.   What do you think?

A surprising number of homeowners are combining backyards, giving up privacy for bigger gardens and more space to entertain. 
Read the story: http://on.wsj.com/KonitF

Would you tear down a fence to share your yard with neighbors? How would you govern and tend such common space? 

Photo: Scott Lewis for The Wall Street Journal

Lance Armstrong's Tour de France titles are in jeopardy, after formal doping charges are levied against him.

Armstrong says he earned those victories, and that the charges are motivated by spite. He says the agency is dredging up old allegations that the Justice Department threw out. "I have never doped," he says. 

Do you believe him? If so, how can he clear his name, and should he even have to?

The fierce competition between cable companies and services like Hulu and Netflix should be good for consumers. But experts say it may actually end up raising TV and Internet bills.

About 9% of homes with TVs cut their cable service in 2011, while another 11% said they planned to do so, a recent survey found.

What are your predictions about the future of cable TV? Do you think most Americans will eventually "cut the cord"?

Ever felt unhappy about your salary? Well it turns out there is a group for you, it's called Underearners Anonymous.  The group even includes a 12-step program to help you confront your fears.

Do you fear asking for a raise?  Has the current economic situation made you more anxious about attaining financial security?

An antitrust investigation is looking into whether cable companies acted improperly to quash competition from online video sites like Hulu, Netflix and Amazon Video.

On average, people watched 21.7 hours of videos online in March 2012, up 47% from a year earlier.

How often do you watch TV shows and movies online? Have you considered "cutting the cord" by unsubscribing to cable?

Contrary to popular belief, risky stocks aren't tied to high returns. In fact, one study found that over 41 years, low-risk stocks outperformed high-risk ones.

One interpretation is that, if risk truly predicts returns, we haven't yet come up with a way to accurately measure risk.

How do you choose your investments? How important is risk when picking stocks?

Verizon's pricing changes are going to be felt by budget-conscious smartphone users, as the price for the basic plan will rise from $70 to $100.  AT&T and other carriers will likely follow Verizon's lead, tossing in flat-rate, unlimited voice and text as an afterthought on aggressively-priced data plans.  

What will the impact be on your budget? Does the change make you rethink your smartphone use?  And when faced with an upgrade under Verizon's new plan, would you choose to pay the full, unsubsidized cost for a new device or would you instead say goodbye to your current unlimited data plan?

The phrase "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance is not a religious truth according to a judge in Massachusetts, who rejected a lawsuit filed by an atheist family.   The judge says the pledge is an exercise designed to inculcate patriotism, and adding the phrase does not turn it into a prayer. 

The plaintiffs will appeal, saying, "“No child should go to school every day, from kindergarten to grade twelve, to be faced with an exercise that defines patriotism according to religious belief."  

What do you think? Does the pledge work as written? Should an alternate version be available for those with differing beliefs?

Companies often give gifts celebrating an employee’s “service anniversary” in an attempt to improve staff engagement and retention.

We invited WSJ readers to share details of corporate gifts they’ve gotten over the years, and learned that the presents can be very hit-or-miss, no matter the industry, company size or years of service.

The recently opened XL Nightclub, Cabaret & Lounge on West 42nd Street is taking a different approach to entertainment in New York City, one that harkens back to an era when performers were the draw at clubs. Co-founder Beto Sutter said that while the word cabaret mplies a certain type of performance, he is presenting dance, music, drag and theater.

Photographer Philip Montgomery, on assignment for The Wall Street Journal, photographed a rehearsal last week for the series Cocktail Hour, which opens June 14.

http://on.wsj.com/L3nn6N

Apple will soon allow its FaceTime video chat to be used over cellular networks instead of just Wi-Fi. But analysts warn the program could rapidly eat up data. 

Users with a basic 250 MB data plan could max it out in a 90-minute FaceTime chat.

How much do you use FaceTime? Are you worried about your data limits?

An estimated 15 million Americans - including 1 in every 13 children - have food allergies. Another 3 million have celiac disease, an autoimmune reaction to gluten. Many others avoid gluten for other health reasons.

More restaurants are designing systems to cater to customers with food allergies and gluten issues.

Do you or your family members have any dietary restrictions? Do you think restaurants do a good job of handling them?

Thinking of getting rid of your old laptop? Resale sites have been flooded with people trying to unload their MacBooks and upgrade to the souped-up new models Apple unveiled yesterday.

An 11-inch MacBook purchased for $999 two years ago might fetch less than $250 today, experts say.

How often do you upgrade your computer? Are you a Mac or a PC?

After the infant disappeared during a family camping trip 32 years ago, the baby's mother spent more than three years in prison. Today the coroner apologized, in tears. The case inspired a movie starring Meryl Streep.

New Orleans residents are rallying to save their local paper, which plans to scale back to just 3 days a week of publishing.  The plan would make New Orleans the largest city in the country without a daily print paper. 

What do you think? Will the effort to preserve daily delivery succeed? Should expectations shift in a new media era?   How important are such institutions?
The bad news: Many baby boomers are likely to get less money from Mom and Dad than they thought. The worse news: They may have to help their parents financially instead.

Median net worth of families fell to $77,300 in 2010 from $126,400 in 2007, a drop of 38.8%.

A look at the Federal Reserve’s Survey of Consumer Finances, a detailed snapshot of household finances conducted every three years:

A new study concludes that "stand your ground" laws increase homicides and have no deterrent effect on crime.

But, as the authors note, the increase could be driven by individuals protecting themselves from imminent harm by using lethal force. It could also be driven by an escalation in violence that, absent the laws, wouldn’t have ended in serious injury for either party, they say.

Check out the study and weigh in.

60% of U.S. kids ages 8 to 11 say they used phone apps, but with mobile games generating $2.7 billion in revenue last year it is parents that are paying.  

Do you pay for your children's phone apps? Do you think the phone industry is too keen to target young consumers?

Apple CEO Tim Cook is expected to unveil a new operating system for iPhones and iPads today. He will be delivering his keynote address today starting at 1 p.m. EST/11 a.m. PST.

Follow updates of Apple's conference throughout the day on the WSJ's live stream: http://on.wsj.com/KmR7W9

Facebook's unique visitors grew a mere 5% in the past year, down from 24% growth in April 2011 and 89% in April 2010.  Do you think Facebook's just maturing, with steady growth still ahead? Have other social networks stolen some of Facebook's momentum?  Or is social networking itself changing? How has your use of Facebook evolved?

Baby boomers are standing to inherit less than previous generations, just as lifespans lengthen to require stronger retirement funding. 

What's happening in your family? Are your parents requiring more support than you expected? Are you changing your plans to ensure a more independent long life?

Sunset Park has views of Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan.  Philip Montgomery for The Wall Street Journal

http://on.wsj.com/LC61vO

Off Duty takes you inside the Belmont Stakes ahead of Saturday's big race. They look at jockey superstitions, horse betting 101 and learn the secrets of horse race calling from legend Tom Durkin.

With Triple Crown contender I'll Have Another out of the race, who do you think will win?

We like to believe that today's authoritarian regimes are dinosaurs—clumsy, stupid, lumbering beasts. 

But William J. Dobson argues that today's smarter dictators now invoke democracy and intimidate quietly.

Americans plan to spend $117 on average for Father's Day - up 10% from last year. The challenge: figuring out what to get Dad.

Unlike Mother's Day flowers, there's no one dominant gift. In one survey, 65% of fathers said they'd rather get nothing than receive another tie.

Are you planning to celebrate Father's Day? What do you think you will get for your father/husband? Dads: what kinds of gifts do you like to receive?

Snowmobiling on water? Yes, it's a sport where eventually everybody sinks. 

What's the most bizarre sport you can think of?

If you're looking for a stable job, it's best to avoid these industries. While jobless claims dropped overall, these five fields are struggling. Together, they account for more than half of all unemployment claims.

Wish you had a wardrobe like Don Draper's? We have an interview with "Mad Men" costume designer Janie Bryant, who has been dressing Jon Hamm for five seasons.

Who is your favorite "Mad Men" character? What do you think of the season so far?

if La Roja manages to win a second consecutive European championship, it's going to have to be considered the greatest sports team of all time, argues WSJ's Matthew Futterman. Does La Roja compare to the golden eras of the Yankees, Canadiens, Celtics, Cowboys, and Bruins?  Which team is your pick for "greatest ever?"

In a rare interview, Dish Chairman Charlie Ergen says that four of his five children won't pay for subscription TV.  He says that the creation of targeted ads which people won't want to skip is the way to rescue television. What do you think? Are there ads you're willing to watch? What else could change about commercially-based programming via satellite or cable that would keep you as a customer?
Mario Lopez, host of 'Extra', sat down with WSJ's Lee Hawkins for an exclusive look at his a career and his new boxing documentary, "Champs."
Giving money to political candidates via text message appears close to approval. Decision could come Friday.
Old is the new cool in videogames as older game titles find new life on mobile devices. Which older games would you like to see revived on your phone?
So it has finally happened - Hawaiian shirts are back in fashion.  Do you think you could pull one off? Or should they be left well alone?

It may no longer pay to commit to a cellphone contract. The average pre-paid user pays $61/month - half the average $122 bill for contract subscribers.

Virgin Mobile announced it will start selling iPhones. Rates will start at $30/month. The downside: customers will have to pay full price for the phones ($549 for an 8GB iPhone 4).

How much do you spend on your cellphone plan? Would you consider switching to a pre-paid plan?

The numbers look grim for U.S. law school students. The average debt they owe is now about $91,100, up 14% from 2008. And one-third of law graduates aren't even working as lawyers.

We asked readers: is law school worth it? We received dozens of responses on Facebook and Twitter, many of them from law school grads.

What do you think? Is a law degree worth the cost and time?

A treadmill might offer better financial returns than Wall Street. Workers who exercise regularly earn 9% higher pay on average than those who don’t. The extra pay more than offsets the cost of a gym membership.

Do you find that people who exercise tend to be better workers? Why do you think they have higher salaries?

Ron Paul's campaign credits his wife's cookbook with helping him secure historic finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire. Carol Paul describes the simple recipes as "libertarian," designed to free mothers to do other things besides cooking.  

Do you have a cooking "ideology?" Is trying to get the family fed a chore you try to simplify, or do you like to put more art and effort into it?

A new generation of retirees rejects assisted-living or aging in place. They're finding options such as living abroad, co-housing and even full-time spa living. 

What are your thoughts about retirement housing? Where would you like to live, and what compromises might you have to make over finances?

The NCAA has become an unlikely training ground for foreign Olympians. At the 2008 Beijing Games, foreign athletes from U.S. universities earned at least 28 medals for their countries—and possibly twice that many.

Are we hurting U.S. Olympic efforts by having international athletes compete at our schools? Or is foreign competition sharpening the skills of American athletes?

When you buy an airplane ticket, what are you really paying for? Middle Seat columnist Scott McCartney crunches the numbers and finds a very low profit margin in the airline industry.

With the price of plane tickets increasing year after year, does this surprise you?

Well this is interesting: Ahead of Euro 2012, only four countries can say that all of their players were born within their borders: the Czech Republic, Russia, Spain and England. 

Which country do you expect to win this year's tournament? How well do you expect hosts Poland and Ukraine to do? Will they get past the group stage?

To stay productive, you might need a To-Don't list, not just a To Do list. 

Columnist Peter Bregman says: "My To-Do list helps me get the right things done. My To-Don’t list helps me avoid spending time on the wrong things."

What's on your To-Don't list? Are there certain things you try to avoid - like checking Facebook at work - to stay productive?

One-third of U.S. law school grads aren't working as lawyers. Tuition is soaring, while salaries are shrinking. Nearly half of 2010 graduates made between $40,000 and $65,000.

Do you think law school is worth it? Why or why not?

Law grads: are you still working in the field? What would you say to someone considering law school?

Having problems sleeping? Does your bedmate's wacky schedule, snoring or blanket-stealing ruin it for you?  Scientists say there are health benefits to smoothing out the wrinkles in your sleep teamwork, and your relationship can improve, too.  

How do you handle incompatibilities? What, short of separate bedrooms, has worked for you?

This story is our most-popular and most-commented this morning.  Will Gov. Walker's victory strengthen GOP anti-union efforts? How should Democrats respond? Will other states now jettison collective bargaining for public workers?

After peaking at an average of 826 minutes per month in 2007, the average use of minutes by mobile phone customers fell to 681 minutes at the end of 2011, according to data tracked by CTIA, the trade group for the U.S. wireless industry.

How often do you make a phone call these days? Do you ever hit your monthly allotment of minutes?
Venus is orbiting between the Earth and sun—an event that won’t happen again until 2117. Catch its transit here:

Apple is planning to delete Google Maps on its iPhones and iPads, replacing it with Apple's own mapping software.

Experts say many users won't even notice the change. What do you think? Do you use Google Maps on your phone? Would you miss it?

The average U.S. household pays nearly $155,000 in 401(k) fees over a lifetime — about 30% of their 401(k) balance, according to a recent report.

An AARP survey found that 62% of 401(k) account holders didn’t know how much they were paying in fees.

Do you know how much you’re paying in 401(k) fees? Are you concerned about them?
Reading a standard IKEA catalog aloud in Thailand can draw strange looks, or worse. Learn why:
Today's story about the effort to recall Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker is number one on our site, as a referendum on collective bargaining. Should state employees have collective bargaining rights?

Scientists are finding psychological and physical benefits to sleeping with a partner, even though people are often bothered by a second sleeper.  If you can remedy the schedule/temperature conflicts, you may find both your health and your relationship benefit.  Do you have trouble sleeping alone?

Nearly 50% of winemakers are planning to raise prices this year. But it's possible to save without resorting to "Two-Buck Chuck."

You could get a $15 Malbec from Argentina that is the same quality as a $30 California Cabernet.

What's your drink of choice? When you're buying a bottle of wine, how important is the price?
Apple and Google are going to war over maps, as Apple preps to launch a proprietary rival.  Do you think Google Maps can be beat?

The original story about the difficulty couples have in talking about sex is still our site's number one most popular story, one week later. Here's a followup with some of the reader responses. Interestingly it's mostly men we've been hearing from.

Coincidence? On the 23rd anniversary of the crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell by 64.89 points, matching the 6/4/89 date of the event.

JUST PASSING THROUGH: Global visibility of Venus' transit across the sun. 

Full story: http://on.wsj.com/KZ3LgZ

Astronomers and amateur stargazers in many parts of the world will get their last shot at glimpsing a rare astronomical phenomenon known as the transit of Venus starting Tuesday afternoon. The event occurs in pairs roughly every century and won't make another appearance until 2117.

Will you be watching? Were you able to see the last transit in 2004?

Question: What's new and scary? Answer: The new GMAT, including a section called 'Integrated Reasoning'. The new test is unveiled tomorrow.

Some test-takers were so worried about the new section they crammed months worth of studying into weeks or even days in order to take the older version of the test before the June 5 switch. 

Would you cram to take the older version of the test? Or does the thought of 12 Integrated Reasoning questions not phase you?

On offer: a pearl necklace, a knife set, luggage and of course a gold watch. 

Have you ever received a company gift to reward you for five, 10, 25 years of service? Did you get to choose the present? Is the tradition old-fashioned, or is it an appropriate way of showing employees that they’re valued? 

Tell us your corporate gift experiences.

Some colleges are dropping student health-insurance plans for the coming academic year and others are telling students to expect sharp premium increases because of a provision in the federal health law requiring plans to beef up coverage.

What do you think of the change? Were previous low-cost, low-benefit student health plans sufficient? Will your son or daughter be affected?

Rita Jahanforuz is Israel's most famous female singer—and she's suddenly big in Iran. 

Are you a fan of her music? Have her songs helped to "puncture the wall'' of tensions between both countries?

Facebook has good reason to make it easier for children to join the site, experts say. 11- to 13-year-olds are more valuable to the company’s bottom line than adults.

Tweens spend $50 billion a year themselves, not including the $170 billion parents spend on them.

What do you think about Facebook making it easier for kids under 13 to join the site?
He jabs, he ducks, he weaves... he sings?!   World Champion boxer Manny Pacquiao goes a round with John Lennon's 'Imagine.'

For the first time in decades, the majority of unemployed Americans have some college education.

In May, 52% of people older than 25 looking for work had at least some college experience, while 48% of the unemployed had only completed high school.

What do you think of this shift?

There's really no such thing as dental insurance, writes Ben Popken. Since even the best dental plans are quickly maxed out, some are turning to price clubs.

The stakes are high: 42% of Americans don't have any dental coverage. And 1 in 4 Americans 65 or older have lost all of their teeth.

What do you think about dental coverage in the U.S.? What kind of plan do you use?
Is poker the next after-school activity for the college bound? Supporters say it rivals chess in teaching skill and strategic thinking. Do you agree?

Facebook is developing a system to allow children younger than 13 to use the social network under parental supervision. The move could help the company tap a new audience, but raises privacy concerns as well. What do you think of the idea?
With implantable technologies, "the person who has a disability today may have a superability tomorrow."

The number of high-income earners paying no income tax has increased over the past few years, according to figures released by the IRS. (High-income earners are those making $200,000/year or more.)

If you could say anything to these folks, what would it be?
How much credit and blame do teachers deserve for student performance?  Vote and tell us what you think.  You may see your opinions in print.

Scientists reported Monday that certain fish migrating from coastal Japan to the southern California coast carried radioactive cesium isotopes. What kind of fish were they?

Test your news knowledge in this week's WSJ Newshound Quiz.

- Pierpont Securities economist Stephen Stanley after dismal U.S. employment and manufacturing reports added to mounting fears about European and Asian economies. The news sent stocks sliding Friday morning. 

Read Full Story: http://on.wsj.com/KR9Ufi 

"Jobs Slowdown Adds to Global Fears", June 1, 2012.

The U.S. added just 69,000 jobs in May, the lowest total in a year. The unemployment rate climbed to 8.2%.

"This is what a jobless recovery looks like," said economist Jeffrey Greenberg.

What do you think about the dismal jobs news? What impact do you think it will have on the election?

The start of summer has an unpleasant downside: higher electricity bills. But you can cut costs by taking a few quick steps.

Replacing an old A/C could cut bills by 30%. Or you could set your thermostat a couple of degrees warmer when you're sleeping, which could save $180 a year.

How often do you use an A/C? Do you take any steps to save money in the summer? What's the most you've shelled out for an electric bill?

Student debt is up 8% over a year ago. A new report shows Americans are reducing other debt but going in deeper for educational loans. What's happening in your household? Is your credit card and mortgage debt lower, while student loans pile on? Is the investment in education worth that level of indebtedness?
Do you think the Justice Department should retry John Edwards?

Do you have a need for speed? And a lawn in desperate need of cutting? Take care of both with these "high speed" riding lawn mowers capable of going up to 8 miles an hour. 

Would a fast ride make cutting the grass more appealing?

Should all U.S. students meet a single set of national proficiency standards? 

Your vote and comment could be featured in print.

“Those who go to preschool will go on to university, will have a graduate education, and their income level will radically improve,” says Dr. Celia Ayala, chief executive officer of Los Angeles Universal Preschool, a nonprofit that funds 325 schools in Los Angeles County, Calif. 

But fewer than half of U.S. kids go to preschool. 

Should preschool be made mandatory? Would preschool education help bridge the gap between students who perform well in school and those who don't?

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has defended his proposal to prohibit the sale of large sodas.  He said banning sales of large soda would help tackle obesity. 
  
What do you think of the idea?  Do you think the state needs to intervene to help curb obesity rates or should it be the individual's responsibility?

Imagine never having to carry cash or a credit card. Payment systems on smartphones are getting more advanced, so this could be the norm within a decade.

The total value of mobile payments could reach $670 billion by 2015, about triple the amount from last year, according to telecom firm Juniper Research.

Have you ever used your mobile phone to buy something or pay a bill? Are you concerned about security? Do you find the prospect of a cashless society exciting or unnerving?

Geeks are the new jocks. Tech companies are luring computer science majors with posh restaurants, iPad giveaways and limo rides to bars. At one event, Google gave away 100 pairs of Android pajamas -- which went fast.

Do you have any unusual recruiting stories? Have you ever been offered perks like this from a prospective employer? What do you think of this trend?

Theme parks are getting more expensive. A one-day pass to Disneyland is now $87, up nearly 10% from earlier this year. Universal Orlando boosted the price of a one-day pass to $88.

Still, there are ways to save this season. Six Flags tickets are as much as 40% cheaper when you buy online.

How often do you go to amusement parks? Do you prefer Disney, Universal or Six Flags parks? Do you think they're worth the price of admission?

Restaurants are now offering tablets to diners to facilitate orders and entertain kids with movies or videogames - often for a fee. What do you think? Would devices interrupt what's supposed to be family time? Or could you relax better when everyone has a diversion? Do the benefits of more efficient ordering and payment outweigh the downsides?

Should tenure for college professors be abolished? 

We’re seeking your opinions for an upcoming special report. Vote in our poll and share your comments for potential inclusion in print.

Aaron Sorkin, writer of "The Social Network" and "The West Wing," takes a seat on the main stage at D10 and tells Walt Mossberg about his next project: adapting Walter Isaacson's book about Steve Jobs into a movie. 

Will you watch the movie?

On college campuses these days, the top nerds are getting a taste of what it's like to be star jocks.

Almost three-quarters (72%) of “affluent” families think their children should contribute to their college costs, according to a survey released Wednesday. The main reason? Most (63%) said they want to make sure their kids take college seriously.

What do you think? Should kids shoulder a portion of the cost? Or is it the parents' responsibility?

Amid widespread unemployment, one of job-seekers' biggest complaints is the now-ubiquitous use of software to screen applications. 

Of greater concern: Electronic gate-keepers that may be raising the bar unnecessarily high for job applicants.

Is Facebook's IPO affecting its popularity? A poll conducted just before it went public found that 51% of people believed the social network’s appeal would fade.

“There’s no doubt that Facebook’s brand was weakened by the events surrounding the IPO,” says Robert Passikoff, founder of Brand Keys. “Originally people felt that they were part of a community and now, for better or for worse, they feel like they are part of a business.”

Do you agree? Has your opinion of Facebook changed since its IPO?

Neil Young has said the digital age is 'degrading' music and is making his new album also available on vinyl. It will cost you if you want to hear it though - $42.38, or $3.85 per song.  

What music format do you listen to? Do you think it is worth paying extra to listen to your favorite musician's albums on vinyl over digital?

What's a safe price to pay for Facebook shares? If you follow the same formula as Google, it's $9 to $15 at most -- less than half its IPO price.

Did the Facebook IPO turn out as you expected? Why do you think it has been unsuccessful? Do you think the stock will rebound or continue to drop?
The Web is riffing on a major typo in Mitt Romney's campaign web app. "Amercia," anyone? Check out some of the memes we've collected. Are people being too hard? Everyone makes mistakes, right?

The options trading period has begun, and so far investors seem to feel there's more downside for Facebook, where shares are off 24% since the IPO. Do you agree? How should the company's shares be valued? What can the company do to recover after what Dealogic calls one of the worst performing debuts of any large company?

By 2017, NASA wants to outsource to private companies all cargo and manned trips to the space station, which orbits 240 miles above the Earth.

How do you feel about private spaceflight? Should NASA be outsourcing?

Researchers are going to great heights to study the effects of low oxygen levels on the heart, lungs and brain in hopes of better understanding diseases that cause heart and lung failure, and sleep apnea. They are conducting their research in the 'thin air' of Mt. Everest's high altitudes. 

Would you trek to Mt. Everest and offer up your lungs to be studied in the name of science?

Tom Brady Sr., the father of the celebrated New England Patriots quarterback, recently said he'd be reluctant to allow his son to play football, if Tom were a teenager today. 

Have concerns over head injuries dissuaded you from letting your child play football? If your son asked for permission to play the game, would you let them? Have you seen a parenting shift away from the sport?

What do the top 50 highest-paid CEOs have in common? They're all men.

Kraft Foods CEO Irene Rosenfeld, the top-paid woman last year, ranked 62nd on the list of more than 300 chief executives compiled by Hay Group. Rosenfeld got just one-fifth of what No. 2 Oracle CEO Larry Ellison earned.

What do you think of the executive pay gap? Do you think it will disappear over time?

President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have differing views on how to spark the economic recovery. But the man chosen for the job probably won't have much influence on the direction of the economy, experts say.

Another thing candidates won't tell you: corporations that help them fare better if they win. Companies that contributed more to a winning presidential candidate beat the market by 6 points in the year after election.

What do you think of campaign promises? How much weight do you give them?

Facebook shares have lost 16% of their value since the company went public on May 18, and Facebook's problem may be souring confidence in the market overall, especially for small investors. Has the Facebook IPO hurt your trust in the market?
Do you use earbuds and noise-canceling headphones at work? Do they help you weed out distractions? What's the best way to handle headphones-in-the-office etiquette?

The latest videogame technology allows you to alter outcomes with your mind. Doctors say it has the potential to improve education and strengthen mental health.  What do you think? Are you interested in trying them? Do you think they might boost brain power?

The Census Bureau reports that 49% of the U.S. population lives in a household where at least one member received some type of government benefit in the first quarter of 2011.  That's up from 30% in the early 1980s, and 44% in 2008.  

What do you think? Is this simply a factor of the recession and our aging nation? How can this trend be reversed?

Many people are dissatisfied with their sex lives, but unable to talk about it with their partner.  Chat Tuesday with Bonds columnist Elizabeth Bernstein about the best way to work through the problems. You can also email your questions to her to be included anonymously at bonds@wsj.com.

We all share two motivations, according to Dan Ariely: "On the one hand, we want to benefit from cheating and get as much money and glory as possible; on the other hand, we want to view ourselves as honest, honorable people. Sadly, it is this kind of small-scale mass cheating, not the high-profile cases, that is most corrosive to society."  

What do you think? Are we all dishonest to some extent? Where do you draw the line to make sure you still feel good about yourself?

In the wake of Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin's decision to turn in his U.S. passport, Capitol Hill is eyeing new tax penalties for those that renounce their citizenship.

The Dow has seen only four “up” days this month, which is tied for the least number of positive days in a month during the index’s history, according to WSJ Market Data Group.

The only other month with this few positive trading days was September 1903.

How do you think the Dow will fare next week? Will we stay at four "up" days for May?
Ahead of Memorial Day, Tom Manion, whose son Travis died while serving as a Marine in Iraq, writes that after more than a decade of war, remarkable men and women are still stepping forward.

From the "flash crash" two years ago to more recent technical glitches at BATS Global Markets and the Nasdaq, it seems electronic markets keep getting their wires crossed, says Intelligent Investor columnist Jason Zweig.

What should the SEC do to improve things? Have you ever experienced problems with computerized trading? Should the process of trading actually be slowed down?

Interest rates are at record lows. The government is devising new programs to help homeowners. The economy and job market are improving, albeit slowly.

But low appraisals and tight lending standards are making it difficult for many borrowers to refinance their mortgage. Here's how to score the best deal:

There are fewer than 100 curly-haired "Barbet" dogs in the U.S. Breeders are hoping to change that so the breed can be included in the Westminster dog show.

A request for proof of President Obama's birthplace caused a controversy this week; what state was behind the kerfuffle? Try your answer and show your news chops in our weekly quiz at http://WSJ.com/Newshound.

The typical wedding costs $25,600, unless you try this approach. The downside: you might get arrested.

More couples are ditching traditional ceremonies for something a bit more impromptu. These "guerrilla weddings" are in art museums, parks or shopping malls. A lot of the time, couples don't ask for permission.

Have you been to any weddings in odd places? What do you think of these nontraditional weddings?

This writer is often asked if human evolution has stopped. He says breakthroughs which allow infertile people to reproduce are "relaxing" natural selection and may be increasing the inheritance of traits which previously prevented humans from surviving to adulthood. Fossils show our brain size has shrunk over the past 20,000 years. 

What do you think? Are humans still evolving and if so, are they headed in the right direction?

The Australian mining boom is leading to jobs for Americans as skilled laborers in the oil, gas and construction industries... with salaries north of $100,00 per year.

Would you move to Australia for work?

"If you write about genetics and evolution, one of the commonest questions you are likely to be asked at public events is whether human evolution has stopped. It is a surprisingly hard question to answer."

One in three romantic and erotic books sold last year were e-books. Back in April, the digital version of "Fifty Shades of Grey" was reportedly selling 6X faster than the print one. (Now it's a bestseller in both forms.)

By stripping erotic novels books of their steamy covers, e-readers eliminated much of the embarrassment of toting them around, experts say.

Do you prefer to read physical books or e-books? Have digital books changed the way you read?

"I probably wouldn't have said the F-word,'' said Carol Bartz, who was fired as chief executive of Yahoo last year.

Cursing at work can damn your career. But some managers swear by it. Deployed at the right moment and in the right setting, a well-chosen curse word can motivate a team, dissolve tension or win over an audience. 

Is it OK to curse occasionally at the office? What do you think of managers who do this?

The TSA has been under fire from Congress and the public for treating all travelers like potential terrorists, inconsistently applying complex rules at checkpoints and putting people in distressing situations. 

John Pistole, administrator of the 10-year-old security agency, is pledging to make changes.

Long-acting forms of contraceptives like IUDs and implants are about 20 times more effective at preventing pregnancy than birth control pills or patches, a study found. 

Those methods "wipe out the human error factor," said Dr. Jeffrey Peipert, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Washington University. "IUDs and implants are more effective because women can forget about them."

Facebook investors filed a civil lawsuit Wednesday alleging that the site and the banks handling the deal failed to disclose crucial information prior to its IPO.

Like the IPO itself, the Facebook lawsuit may disappoint shareholders. The number of similar suits have been on the rise, but settlement payouts have plummeted in recent years.

What do you think of the Facebook lawsuit? Do you think shareholders should get payouts?

The TSA vows improvements after criticism from Congress and the public for treating all passengers like potential terrorists: mom told she couldn't take an ice pack and empty bottles for breast milk through checkpoint, teen's insulin pump damaged by body scanner,  4-year-old girl patted down.  What do you think? Is the TSA erring on the side of caution or have their procedures crossed the line?

What will you be doing for a living in 10 years? How is technology changing where we work, and what skills are most valued?  Brian David Johnson "lives" in the year 2022.  

Chat with him directly today at 1 p.m. ET or ask questions and offer up your views of the future below.  Could janitors be more valuable than neurosurgeons? And when exactly is the robot apocalypse?

Hospitals are about to go wireless, using bandage-like sensors to send vital sign measurements to medical professionals.

Tomorrow the FCC will vote on opening up some spectrum for these wireless monitors to use. 

Do you think wireless monitoring of vital signs is a step in the right direction? Or unnecessary?

Ever heard of or watched the annual Eurovision Song Contest? 

With crazy costumes, tacky dance routines and la-la lyrics, this venerable European institution is the world's biggest nonsporting TV event, with more viewers than the Super Bowl or the Oscars. 

Now, it is attracting more viewers than ever in the U.S. thanks to live streaming online.

After shrinking during the recession, U.S. homes are getting bigger. Last year, the average home size jumped 5% to 2,505 square feet.

Home builders are crediting "McMansions" - typically homes larger than 3,000 square feet - for fueling a rise in new home sales.

What do you think about this trend? How much do you value having a spacious home?
What happened to MF Global’s customer’s money? Join the producers of a Frontline documentary, “The Six Billion Dollar Bet” and WSJ’s Aaron Lucchetti at 3 p.m. EDT today. Ask your questions now.

“Dynamic,” “organizational” and “effective" are some of the most overused words in LinkedIn profiles. Because such catch-all words tend to be vague, they’re usually not the most efficient mode of communication, experts say.

Which buzzwords are your least favorite? Which ones are you guilty of using yourself?

Best Buy is losing ground to online retailers. But experts say brick-and-mortar stores offer better deals than Amazon for some electronics. 

People who buy online may now be paying a premium for the convenience of not getting off the couch.

If you're buying electronics, are you more likely to get them online or at a physical store? Where do you usually find the best prices?

Many companies use the word "innovation" to convey monumental change when the progress they're describing is quite ordinary.

A search of SEC annual and quarterly reports shows companies mentioned some form of the word "innovation" 33,528 times last year, a 64% increase from five years ago.

Do you think "innovation" is becoming a meaningless word?
What are you planning to read this summer? We're interested in your picks for an upcoming roundup we'll be publishing.

It's not just working parents who step back from work to reclaim their life balance.  

Is life simpler for singles? Do they have a harder time drawing boundaries between work and personal time? Do managers assign them more work and longer hours because they don't have so many obvious family obligations and conflicts in their schedules?
Congrats Donald and Peta on your 11th season 'Dancing With the Stars' victory.  Do you agree with the judges' decision? Or did another couple deserve to win?

Only 9% of U.S. voters said they had a great deal or quite a bit of confidence in Wall Street. 13% gave high marks to health-insurance companies, and 16% to the federal government, according to a new WSJ poll.

In a poll conducted by The Wall Street Journal and NBC News, 62% of those surveyed said the presidential candidates’ positions on gay marriage make no difference in how they might vote, while 17% said they are more likely to support Obama and 20% said they are more likely to support Romney.

About 30% of each man’s supporters say their candidate’s views reinforce their support for him, with only 7% or 8% of supporters for Mr. Obama and Mr. Romney respectively expressing concerns.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture said Tuesday it had confirmed the first new case of mad-cow disease since 2006 after the illness was suspected in a California dairy cow.

The cow was tested as part of the USDA's ongoing surveillance system for the disease which tests about 40,000 cows per year. This is the fourth case of mad-cow disease reported in the U.S.

Officials said no meat from the animal entered the human food supply.

Apple’s earnings just hit the Tape.

For the fiscal second-quarter, the company earned  $11.6 billion, or $12.30 a share, on sales of $39.2 billion.

A year ago, the company earned $5.99 billion, or $6.40 a share, on sales of $24.67 billion.

The Street consensus was for EPS of $10.02. You could say they beat the Street.

Gillette observed more than one million shaves last year, watching men through a two-way mirror at its research centers in Boston and Reading, England. Starvation in India is a brutal but little-discussed reality. We are publishing a six-part series on this issue this week: http://on.wsj.com/starving_in_india2.

Tulsi Manjhi, pictured here with his daughter, recalls laying silently next to his wife, Gita Devi, on a khattiya, a cot made of bamboo and coconut fiber after she gave birth to her sixth child.

Villagers recall her losing weight rapidly and say they couldn’t help because they didn’t have sufficient food either.

“I was hungry too but she couldn’t even get up,” Mr. Manjhi recalls. “I tried to feed her jinghi (leaves from trees) once.” 

She died eight days after giving birth. An activist who advises India’s Supreme Court on food security issues deemed Gita Devi’s a starvation death.

PHOTO CREDIT: Ashwin Parulkar for The Wall Street Journal. The picture was taken in the Banwara village in India in November 2011.

"No one wants to die. Even people who want to go to heaven don’t want to die to get there. And yet death is the destination we all share. No one has ever escaped it. And that is as it should be, because Death is very likely the single best invention of Life. It is Life’s change agent. It clears out the old to make way for the new. Right now the new is you, but someday not too long from now, you will gradually become the old and be cleared away. Sorry to be so dramatic, but it is quite true.

"Your time is limited, so don’t waste it living someone else’s life. Don’t be trapped by dogma — which is living with the results of other people’s thinking. Don’t let the noise of others’ opinions drown out your own inner voice. And most important, have the courage to follow your heart and intuition. They somehow already know what you truly want to become. Everything else is secondary."
